Ecology and Evolution (Lab) [BIO-3012/ ES-3301] [BIO-3012/ ES-3301-1]

Faculty Name
Dipendra Nath Basu [dipendra.basu@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shivani [shivani.krishna@ashoka.edu.in ] ;
Overview

Students will be introduced to quantitative methods of research in ecology and evolution including experimental design, data collection, analysis, interpretation and scientific writing using field, laboratory and bioinformatic studies. They will work with plant and animal models from local ecosystems to empirically test concepts in population growth, competition, resource utilization, foraging behavior, communication, ecological parameters on bacterial growth (e.g. pH & temperature), data mining, sequence analyses and phylogenetic reconstruction. The course aims at giving an experience of concepts and methods discussed in theory courses of ecology, evolutionary biology, bioinformatics, and biostatistics. Towards the end of this course, students will be able to design and implement appropriate methods for sampling individuals, populations and communities and ask questions on their diversity, stability, productivity, and evolutionary history. Modules dealing with behavioral experiments will also demonstrate potential errors that arise due to observer bias, the significance of blinded methods, and other potential ways to improve the reliability of the data collected.

Below is the tentative schedule for the course

1. Hidden battles: inferring intraspecific competition using spatial patterns (using leaf galls)

2. Patterns of morphological variation: geometric morphometric analysis

3. Mutualistic partnerships and their economies: analyzing plant-pollinator interactions (optimal foraging)-I

4. Mutualistic partnerships and their economies: analyzing plant-pollinator interactions (optimal foraging)-II

5. Life-dinner battles: predator-prey interactions in different ecological and behavioral contexts-I (social spiders)

6. Life-dinner battles: predator-prey interactions in different ecological and behavioral contexts-II (social spiders)

7. Ecology of interspecific competition (Bt-Pe)

8. Evolutionary outcomes of interspecific competition (Bt-Pe)

9. Quantitative morphology of divergent traits in insects

10. Phylogenetic reconstruction

11. Sexual selection and mate choice

12. Evolution of antibiotic resistance-I (Tracking evolution as it happens)

13. Evolution of antibiotic resistance-II

Note that this is a tentative course structure and hence, is subject to further change, if necessary

Learning Outcomes

This course comprises 13 laboratory modules. Each module aims at revisiting some of the concepts introduced in the lectures and will provide a hands-on
experience of general methods used in ecological and evolutionary biology studies. Thinking analytically and scientific writing are best developed through practice.
Thus, actively engaging in writing laboratory reports will serve as a useful tool to improve students’ writing skills.

Grading Rubric

1) Weekly reports (90%): Each lab report is worth 10 marks. Final grading will consider the best nine reports. Reports need to be submitted before the following week’s practical. Delayed submission of weekly reports with no prior extension requests will result in a deduction of marks (12-23 hrs after deadline: 1 mark; 24-72 hrs after deadline: 2 marks;  >72 hrs: 5 marks). The weekly lab report written based on the experiment conducted should comprise a brief introduction, aims/objectives, methods used, analyses and results, discussion, and conclusion.

2) Lab/Field etiquettes and class participation (10%)

Experiments will be carried out in pairs unless instructed otherwise during the class. Since the lab reports will be based on ones’ own results, attendance to the labs and active participation is strongly encouraged. Please communicate in advance to the instructors if there is any unavoidable reason for missing the lab. Each student has to write their own report. Any sort of plagiarism or copying will not be tolerated. Late submissions will be accepted only under exceptional circumstances of emergencies or medical conditions or prior permission from course instructors.

Attendance Policy

Attendance is mandatory

It is not possible to repeat experiments that have been missed.

Announcements related to the course will be made on google classroom and all the required materials will be shared in the class drive folder. Please inform the TAs if you have any trouble accessing the material.

While in the field, utmost care must be taken so as not to disturb the life forms. The following precautions should also be taken:

-Full pants and closed shoes are preferable over shorts and sandals/ slippers. This is for the sake of protecting oneself from thorns etc.

-Hats/caps if required.

Histories of South Asian Art: From the Earliest Times to the Present [VA-3006/ HIS-3804] [VA-3006/ HIS-3804-1]

Overview

Course Description

What is Art and who is it meant for? What is specifically South Asian about South Asian Art? What does it mean to think of South Asia and Art as analytical categories? Did South Asian Art always exist? Or were historical processes involved in the making of the field? Where do we locate the “genesis” of art in South Asia? Did art forms in South Asia emerge in a zone of cultural and social isolation? Or can we trace trajectories of trans-regional contacts, encounters, and exchanges as central to the shaping of the field of South Asian Art? What is space of tradition and innovation in the visual arts of South Asia? Did arts of South Asia “influence” artistic practices in other regions? How did artists at different points in history think about the region we identify as South Asia? Seeking to address some of these questions, this course examines aspects of the visual arts of South Asia from its earliest traces in cave paintings and stone implements to sculpture, painting, illustrated manuscripts, calligraphy, and architecture. The course follows a chronological scale, from pre-history to c. 1980s.

The vast geographical as well as the temporal span of the field will restrict the course from delivering an encyclopaedic survey. The course will prioritize intensive analysis of selected themes. Rather than placing the teleology of South Asian “art” solely in the context of changing dynastic histories, the course takes up specific themes in art across a range of objects, artefacts, archaeological sites, built spaces, religious and political symbols, and institutions of art pedagogy and exhibitions. In the process we address the questions of image, icon, and representations of body, portraiture, architectural forms, landscape, in the context of social and ideological changes, aesthetic turns, shifting patrons and markets, and introduction of new material media. The course will probe both ‘South Asia’ and ‘South Asian Art’ as stable (art) historical categories and map the new methodologies and vocabularies employed by art historians.

Class discussions will form the basis for compulsory museum/ gallery/ site classes to the National Museum of India (New Delhi, contingent on the continuity of the existing institution, physical classes), NGMA (New Delhi, physical classes), Delhi Art Gallery (Delhi, physical classes), National Handloom and Handicrafts Museum (New Delhi, physical classes), Indian Museum, Kolkata (Virtual), British Museum (Virtual), Victoria and Albert Museum (Virtual) and the MET (Virtual) which will enable us to study the works of art in their institutional locations and explore the visual dynamics of organization of exhibition spaces.

Learning Outcomes

a) Identify and analyze aspects of works of art and visual images in different materials and media using appropriate vocabulary.

b) Explore the main trends in the development of Art History and Visual Culture by accessing the critical essential skills.

c) Evaluate the approaches of artists, art historians, visual anthropologists and curators to the field of visual arts.

d) Develop the interests for a future training in critical art historical training and art curatorial programme.

Introduction to Neuroscience/ Biological Psychology [PSY-2011/ BIO-2103/ BIO-6103] [PSY-2011/ BIO-2103/ BIO-6103-1]

Faculty Name
Bittu R [bittu@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The goal of this class is to enable students to understand how a biological system mostly composed of salty proteinaceous water bounded by fat is able to signal information, perform complex computations and produce behaviour. We will start by understanding how single neurons can perform computations and can be understand in the same framework as electronic circuitry. We will understand then how complex information processing and calculation can happen as a result of the ways in which multiple neurons signal to and connect to one another. We will then look at how the brain is organized, and study the nervous systems of humans and other animals, approaching this through the lens of the various tools that neuroscientists have historically used to study neuronal connectivity and the brain. We will cover the electrical properties of nerve cells and voltage dependent membrane permeability; channels, transporters, neurotransmitters and their receptors; synaptic transmission; the brain and its development and plasticity. We will also study complex brain functions and the neural basis of complex cognition, learning and information processing. We explore the ways in which the neuronal processes underlying behaviour have been deduced from various animal models of behaviour, and ways in which genetics and the environment shape the systems that produce behaviour during development. We will explore sensory perception and motor movement in depth.

Learning Outcomes

This course is offered to both biology and psychology students and covers the same ground as a standard course on Biological Psychology. It aims to introduce neuroscience as a specialized discipline, and to enable students to understand how a biological system is able to signal information, perform computations and produce behaviour. This course will also use teaching tools in the discussion section that enable an intuitive grasp of neural processes, such as simulations to understand how various factors affect neuronal functioning, and experiments to demonstrate neurons in action and how various interventions affect neuronal functioning.

In order to equip students to become familiar with the level of rigour needed to think through some of these questions, we will also look at how to survey and evaluate literature in the field of biological psychology, how to quickly but accurately read graphs and how to cite literature.

We then turn to the question of how we learn, how we absorb new material, the ways in which our neural systems tend to conflate correlation and causation, and how critical thinking and environmental training can change learning patterns and feedback to change the structure of the brain. We will take a quick look at the neural basis of complex and interesting phenomena such as motivation, emotion, cognition, consciousness, attention. We will end with an exploration of how neural systems can exhibit pathology, how neurodegeneration and trauma can impact the system, and how medication and drugs work, with a focus on the limitations of what we collectively understand and the pressing need for further research to take forward the field. This course eventually hopes to make clear the relationship between brain and behaviour.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The recommended textbook for this course is Biological Psychology by James W. Kalat (Kalat, J. W. (2008). Biological Psychology. Calif: Wadsworth, Cengage Learning). I have a physical copy of the 11th edition. Faculty Name
Sraman Mukherjee [sraman.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course explores global social formations from the fifteenth century of the Common Era to our present times through the prism of visual images. We specifically focus on the centrality of visual archives in mapping histories of European colonialism under Spanish, Portuguese, Dutch, French, and British empires. The course will address a range of colonial formations and diverse articulations of nationalist thought and consciousness in different parts of the world through different visual forms across a range of media, sites, and objects. Beginning from naturalist paintings and drawings of unknown landscapes and oceans, descriptions of plants and animals, of unknown humans and exotic objects, the course moves on to explore diverse media and technologies of visual (re)productions like water colour, oil painting, lithographs, oleographs, chromolithographs, aquatints, photographs and the moving image, and maps different sites of visual simulations like cabinet de curiosities, ‘freak shows’, world exhibitions, metropolitan, colonial, and postcolonial public museums, art galleries, institutes of fine arts, crafts and design pedagogy. The course argues that global histories of colonialism, nationalism, and decolonization can be partially explored as histories of encounters, violent conflicts, tortuous negotiations, and often uneasy accommodations played out at the register of the visual image. The course urges us to rethink that the notions of metropolis and colony, empire and nation, colonizer and colonized, alien and indigenous, as they are configured and reconfigured in the archives of the visual image, are historically relative, often fluid categories, having only situational relevance. Moving away from a purely Euro-centric discussion of the beginnings of Art and Art History, this course seeks to move towards a global history of art.

Class discussions will form the basis for compulsory museum, gallery, site classes to the National Museum of India (New Delhi, contingent on the continutity of the existing institution, physical classes), NGMA (New Delhi, physical classes), Delhi Art Gallery (Delhi, physical classes), National Handloom and Handicrafts Museum (New Delhi, physical classes), Indian Museum, Kolkata (Virtual), British Museum (Virtual), Victoria and Albert Museum (Virtual) and the MET (Virtual) which will enable us to study the works of art in their institutional locations and explore the visual dynamics of organization of exhibition spaces. Overview

Exploring antimicrobial resistance: Re-sensitization of antibiotic resistant bugs

This microbiology module is designed as an inquiry-based laboratory course. It will investigate antimicrobial resistance (AMR) from multiple angles, incorporating aspects of molecular microbiology, microbial ecology and evolution. The aim is to expose students to how real research stories are built, while simultaneously teaching laboratory tools and techniques such as microbiological methods, PCR, mutagenesis and experimental evolution. Students are expected to participate in generating and evaluating evidence-based data. As a bonus, in cases that yield interesting results, students could also gain the opportunity to further analyse (beyond the class time) and publish their findings, thus gaining valuable research experience. In order to ensure personal attention and hands-on training, the number will be limited to 15 students (groups of 3 X 5).  Two trained senior research assistants will be needed to carry out prior preparatory work, organize and help with carrying out the activities.

Summary of course organization:

In this 12 week module, students will:

i)  Document and analyse local environmental AMR using both culture-based and PCR based approaches

ii) Compare existing clinical with environmental AMR gene data (sequence analysis)

iii) Carry out DNA extractions, PCR and experimental evolution (hands-on)

iv) Understand molecular mechanisms of resistance

v) Track adaptation to antibiotics in laboratory vs environmental bacteria, and attempt to  re-sensitize antibiotic resistant strains using bacteriophages, selection and

directed evolution

Learning Outcomes

 

 In addition to screening for AMR gene presence, students will also gain exposure to microbial ecology by looking for inhibition of environmental and lab microbes by antibiotic producing bacterial species (Streptomyces sp). Subsequently, we will explore manipulative laboratory-based solutions to tackling AMR via mutagenesis (dry lab only) and directed evolution (experimental). During this process, they will be trained in several lab techniques, analytical thinking, evaluating scientific evidence and good microbiology lab practices. The data on local AMR and specific evolved lines generated by this lab course can serve as a cumulative undergraduate resource over time and be followed up to ask other and deeper questions.

Grading Rubric

We will follow the Ashoka rubric. There will be a viva (20% marks) in addition to in-class evaluation (20%) and overall performance in the experiments (60%).

Attendance Policy

Faculty Name
Ananya Sharma [ananya.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is concerned with gender ‘in’ International Relations. It is comprehensive introduction to a way of analyzing and researching global politics and international relations that takes gender seriously as a category of analysis. More specifically, it is concerned with how ideas of war, peace, sovereignty, violence, foreign policy, governance and political economy are sustained by specific masculinities and femininities, and how these particular gender constructions impacton the lives of particular groups of men and women. Set against this, the aim of the course is mainly threefold: firstly, to(re)introduce how the discipline has traditionally thought about war and peace; secondly, to reveal the gendered constructions and inequalities that mark the traditional scholarship; and thirdly, to evaluate the specific contribution that feminist critiques have made as part of the so-called ‘Critical Turn’ in IR. Gender is understood here not as a synonym for ‘woman’ but as a hierarchical coding of masculinity and femininity that pervades social relations and institutional practices, with systemic (though not deterministic) effects on inequalities. Gender meanings and practices permeate our lives, and a closer look at these processes is more illuminating than many anticipate, with relevance and implications for who we are, how we think, and how we act – as individuals, groups, communities and nation-states.

Overview

Course Description

What do we mean by magic, science and religion & what are the similarities & differences between them? Are these concepts contradictory or complementary? Are the boundaries between them clear or complicated? And in what ways are they different? How do these belief systems develop, evolve, and function in the practice of everyday life? This course explores magic, science, and religion as systems of explaining and controlling events. While magic, science, and religion may seem like stable domains, we examine how the meaning of these categories shifts over time and across contexts, so much so that the difference between them often seems to break down altogether. By focusing on cross-cultural differences in systems of belief, we raise fundamental questions about human nature itself, and the basic human need to interpret and influence events. We will explore key debates in social scientific (particularly anthropological) research on magic, science, and religion, and conduct their own original research projects involving first-hand observations of magical, scientific, and religious practices.

Overview

This course builds on the methods and concepts introduced in Macroeconomics I and II. The aim of this course is to learn: 1) recursive competitive equilibrium models that feature individual heterogeneity, with some coverage of firm level heterogeneity; and 2) how to numerically solve for the equilibrium of these economies. These models are helpful to analyze a wide range of questions pertaining to business cycles, income distribution, asset pricing etc. The course will start with a discussion of aggregation with heterogeneous agents. It will then consider the benchmark of complete markets and tests of the same, after which it will lay the foundations for models of incomplete markets, emphasizing the precautionary saving motive. These strands will coalesce in the canonical standard incomplete markets model of Bewley-Aiyagari-Huggett. The last set of lectures shall discuss extensions of the standard incomplete markets model, economies with heterogeneous firms, and conclude with a brief introduction to heterogeneous agent New Keynesian models.

Introduction to Ecocriticism: Climate Fiction [ENG-3038/ ENG-5038/ ES-3701] [ENG-3038/ ENG-5038/ ES-3701-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

As if being a serious political and geophysical problem were not enough, the climate crisis is also a cultural problem. “Climate fiction,” or "cli-fi," is a term that has emerged in recent decades designating a corpus of literature marked by its engagement with global warming. Defined in this way, the term is not reducible to any single genre, and examples range from the “high-“ to “lowbrow.” If we understand "cli-fi" as being a literary and cinematic response to the scientific consensus that human activity is warming the planet, then it is a phenomenon of the late 20th and 21st centuries. In this course, however, we will be taking a broader historical approach. For one thing, the history of climate science is almost as old as the fossil fuel economy itself: Svante Arrhenius first described the greenhouse effect in 1896, and he was building on science that goes back at least to the 1850s. But more significantly, pegging climate fiction to atmospheric science implicitly posits a one-way street between scientific discourse and literary production, an assumption that is, put bluntly, wrong. In this course, therefore, we will read not only relatively recent literary texts that dramatize the climate crisis as we understand it today, but also more historical texts that think about the atmosphere both as a geophysical phenomenon as well as an aesthetic one. The course will include literature, theory, and film, with writers and directors ranging from H.G. Wells and Thomas Mann to Alexis Wright, Margaret Atwood, Bong Joon-ho, and Amitav Ghosh. In addition to the big question of representing something as dynamic as the atmospheric system, we will take up related problems such as deep time, the limits of realism and the possibilities of speculative fiction, and questions of environmental justice and ethics.

courseTitle: Visual Culture of Indian Painting: Courtly Traditions
description:
Visual Culture of Indian Painting: Courtly Traditions [VA-2001/ HIS-3806] [VA-2001/ HIS-3806-1]

Faculty Name
Sraman Mukherjee [sraman.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

As mobile and portable objects,  the visually saturated paintings  made for Mughal, Rajput and Decani courts in pre modern India had many lives. Accessible today though museum collections the world over, they were once collected  by  elite patrons to fashion courtly identities. This course will lead students to explore pictorial language used in these paintings and see the framing of subjectivities within them. Beyond this, the course will uncover the social lives of these works as material objects,  shaped by transregional networks that allowed cultural flows between people, places and artifacts. 

Students will be led to examine the place of these paintings within the arts of the book with transcultural connections, from Europe  to  China.  They will look at the histories of  artistic practices involved in the making of these highly crafted works of art. What did visual style mean to artists and patrons, and how is it seen today? How do contemporary artists from India and Pakistan view this legacy and interpret it?

The course is interdisciplinary in approach. It will bring literary, performative and sensory studies  to bear on understanding the visual using art historical frameworks.  This will explored through themes both as subject matter of the paintings, and as a lens for understanding the affective, cultural and political value of these works. The focus will be on  paintings made between the fifteenth  and the eighteenth centuries, and on contemporary reflections on this practice by artists from South Asia.  

Learning Outcomes

Upon completing this course students will be able to: 

  • Locate transcultural and cosmopolitan encounters in premodern India through the arts of the book.
  • Read the past in the present though contemporary art works that reference these traditions.
  • Trace the agency of individual artists in the creation of highly calibrated art works.
  • Engage with a contemporary artist re- working miniature painting formats, and/ or an exhibition featuring works by ‘contemporary miniaturists’ 
  • Curate a digital exhibition  as term end project

. 

                 . 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

General readings: 

Eaton, Richard M. India in the Persianate Age: 1000-1765. Penguin UK, 2019 , pp 430-553, 316-349

Asher, Catherine B., and Cynthia Talbot. India Before Europe. Cambridge University Press, 2006.pp 272-348

Between the scroll, the pothi and the codex.  

This module is an introduction to the arts of the book in India , before the advent of the Mughals.  It will look  at Indic and Islamicate approaches to book making in circulation in the fifteenth and sixteenth with regard to design, storytelling  and materiality.  Students will specifically look at colour and paper as  material agents of visuality. They will also examine hybridity as a cultural feature, while  exploring  the movement of artifacts and artists. 

J. P. Losty, The Arts of  the Book in India, (The British Library) 1982. 37-54

Kim, Jinah. Garland of Visions: Color, Tantra, and a Material History of Indian Painting. United States, University of California Press, 2021.

Bailkin, Jordanna. "Indian yellow: Making and breaking the imperial palette." Journal of material culture 10.2 (2005): 197-214.

Flood, Finbarr Barry. "Before the Mughals: Material Culture of sultanate North India." Muqarnas Online 36.1 (2019): 1-39.

 

Between Europe and Asia

Between the sixteenth and the eighteenth centuries the profuse output of paintings produced at the courts of the Mughals , the Deccani Sultanates and Rajput rulers was  in many ways the result of transregional and transcultural encounters.  The courts of the Deccani Sultanates and the Mughal court were actively connected with Persia and Europe through ties of trade, religion, politics, but also through networks linking  persons of talent including artists, poets and scholars. This module will look at paintings  on cloth, the  art of Ebru or marbelling on paper, a manuscript on esoteric practices  within the Deccan , and  Muraqqa or albums created at the Mughal courts, to explore cosmopolitanism  in pre modern India. 

Rice, Yael. "The Global Aspirations of the Mughal Album." Rembrandt and the Inspiration of India (2018): 61-77.

Khullar, Sonal, ed. Old Stacks, New Leaves: The Arts of the Book in South Asia. University of Washington Press, 2023.

Natif, Mika. Mughal occidentalism: artistic encounters between Europe and Asia at the courts of India, 1580-1630. Brill, 2018.

Flatt, Emma J. The courts of the Deccan sultanates: Living well in the Persian cosmopolis. Cambridge University Press, 2019.154.

Green, Nile. "Ostrich eggs and peacock feathers: Sacred objects as cultural exchange between Christianity and Islam." Al-Masaq 18.1 (2006): 27-78.

Haidar, Navina Najat, and Marika Sardar. Sultans of Deccan India, 1500–1700: Opulence and Fantasy. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2015

 

On style and meaning

What can pictorial style harbour within its language? Can style be manipulated to convey political messages? Students will look at paintings that were produced at  Rajput courts to see how artists made paintings that recorded resistance or accommodation to the Mughals. 

Baxandall, Michael. Painting and experience in fifteenth century Italy: a primer in the social history of pictorial style. Oxford Paperbacks, 1988.

 Aitken, Molly Emma. The Intelligence of Tradition in Rajput Court Painting. Yale University Press, 2010

Singh, Kavita. "A Knowing Look: Appropriation and Subversion of the Mughal Idiom in Rajput Paintings of the Eighteenth Century." Synergies in Visual Culture/Bildkulturen im Dialog. Wilhelm Fink, 2013. 257-268.

 

On love and desire  

Students will explore the treatment of love as an emotion across literary and visual idioms in circulation.   How did poets and artists respond to differing notions of love drawn from rasa canonical literature and Persianate traditions?  Beyond literary tropes, students will look at representations of ideal women as objects of  desire, and examine the framing of the gaze within paintings from Pahari and Rajasthani courts.  

Readings 

Aditya Behl, Love’s  Subtle Magic: An Indian Islamic Literary Tradition 1379- 1545. OUP New York 2012.

Miśra, Bhānudatta. Bouquet of Rasa” & “River of Rasa. NYU Press, 2009.

Desai, Vishakha N. "Loves of Rādhā in the" Rasikapriyā" Verses and Paintings." Ars Orientalis (2000): 83-92.

Aitken, Molly Emma. "Spectatorship and femininity in Kangra style painting." Representing the body–gender issues in Indian art. Kali for women–in association with the Book Review Literary Trust, New Delhi (1998): 82-101

 

Artists: circulation and ateliers.

Painters and artists often led itinerant lives, moving between courts seeking patronage or being actively solicited. How did their mobility impact their art? Students will attempt to reimagine their lives and histories in the course of this module. This module will look also  at workshop and atelier practices to understand the production of these art works. 

Readings

 Pamuk, Orhan. My name is Red. Vol. 331. Everyman's Library, 2010.

Beach, Milo Cleveland, Eberhard Fischer, and B. N. Goswamy. "Masters of Indian Painting, I: 1100-1650." Zürich: Artibus Asiae (2011).

Seyller, John. "Farrukh Beg in the Deccan." Artibus Asiae55.3/4 (1995): 319-341.

Rice, Yael. "Workshop as Network: A Case Study from Mughal South Asia." Artl@ s Bulletin 6.3 (2017): 4.

 

Music, poetry and devotion

Paintings produced at courts and beyond created an aesthetic world that was multisensorial. The creation of this aesthetic was linked to ideas of pleasure and luxury but also to that of polity. Students will look at the cult of Nauras  at the court of Ibrahim Adil Shah, in the Deccan, at representations of musical soirees at Mewar and the Pahari hill courts, at paintings on cloth made for Vallabh Sampradaya at Nathdwara, and for the poet – ruler Savant Singh at Kishangarh.  

Pollock, Sheldon. A rasa reader: Classical Indian aesthetics. Columbia University Press, 2016.

Orsini, Francesca, and Katherine Butler Schofield. Tellings and Texts: Music, Literature and Performance in North India. Open Book Publishers, 2015.

Rajamani, Imke, Margrit Pernau, and Katherine Butler Schofield. Monsoon feelings: A history of emotions in the rain. Niyogi, 2018.

Pauwels, Heidi. Mobilizing Krishna’s World: The Writings of Prince Savant Singh of Kishangarh. University of Washington Press, 2017

 

Kingship, Connoisseurship, Portraiture 

The module looks at portraiture as a mode for expressing ideals of kingship, for political rhetoric or as notions of selfhood. Students will look at the differing representational approaches to portraiture practiced  at Mughal, Deccani and Rajput courts to examine the differing uses portraits were put to. 

Readings:  

John Seyller, 'A Mughal Code of Connoisseurship,' Muqarnas, 17, 2000: pp 177-202. 

Gulbransen, Krista Hall. "Jahāngīrī portrait shasts: Material-discursive practices and visuality at the Mughal court." postmedieval 11.1 (2020): 68-79.

Branfoot, Crispin. Portraiture in South Asia Since the Mughals: Art, Representation and History. Bloomsbury Publishing, 2018.

 

The Past in the Present : copying and citation 

Students will examine at ways in which works were copied as a mode of transmission, and at how this practice itself became a way of  commenting, wittily, and often subversively, on political contexts. They will be led to see this practice and its ‘re use’ in contemporary contexts, in the works of contemporary painters from Pakistan and India.

Readings: 

Desai, Vishakha N. "Reflections of the past in the present: Copying processes in Indian painting." Perceptions of South Asia’s Visual Past (1994): 135-148.

.Saraf, Varunika. "A Market for Fakes:" Miniature" Painting in Rajasthan, 1960-2000." MARG- 69.3 (2018): 54-63.

Whiles, Virginia. Art and Polemic in Pakistan: Cultural Politics and Tradition in Contemporary Miniature Painting. Tauris Academic Studies, 2010.

Grading Rubric

Students are assessed continually through the entire semester including active class and participation, class presentations, assignments and an end curatorial project. The assessment and grading pattern is as follows:

 Class participation and engagement : 10% of total grades. 

Class presentation and assignments : 60% of total grades

Assignment 1 - Arts of the book- 5%

Assignment 2 -Transcultural Encounters in the Muraqqa- 15%

Assignemnt 3 _ Courtly Rasa/ Meta Pictures/ Political Allegory- 20%

Assignment 4-Site Visits- Connecting the pAt and the Present - 20%

 

End semester curatorial project

Digital Muraqqa :  30% of total grades.

90% attendance is mandatory

Faculty Name
Sandeep Ameta [sandeep.ameta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Fundamental chemical principles govern the highly regulated biological systems and their environment. Therefore, to appreciate the complexity of biological systems, we also need to look at them from a chemical perspective. This course aims to introduce basic chemistry concepts necessary for studying biological systems. The course is designed to provide a framework to students for understanding the basics of chemistry, biomolecules, their interactions, and mechanisms. In addition, the course will also offer a glimpse of how various chemical entities and their interactions led to the transition from chemistry to biology. The first half of the course will cover the basics of chemical bonds, structures, chemical thermodynamics, reactions, equilibrium, and kinetics. The second half will teach about the basic building blocks constituting life (nucleic acids, lipids, carbohydrates, sugar, protein, and concepts of metabolism).

Learning Outcomes

During the course, students will be taught two broad aspects:

  • What are biological molecules made of?
  • How do they interact, assemble, and process in the biological systems?

Within this broad theme, at the end of this course students, we aim to have students familiarize themselves with basic chemical concepts that are useful in biology. This includes an understanding of the basics of chemical bonds, solutions, chemical interactions, thermodynamics, chemical reactions, chemical kinetics, enzyme kinetics, binding kinetics, biomolecules, and their function in biology. Students will also be familiarize with how these biomolecules are synthesized and maintained in the body. Additionally, through this course, students should be able to evaluate and make connections between the key chemical components of life and how these components can interact within the biological systems.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Soft- Matter Physics [PHY-4720/ PHY-6720 ] [PHY-4720/ PHY-6720 -1]

Faculty Name
Gautam Iqbal Menon [gautam.menon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This  course will provide an introduction to soft condensed matter physics, the phenomena, the physics underlying such materials, the experiments that inform us about them and the insightful theoretical ideas that enable us to make sense of them.

Although standard condensed matter physics/solid state physics courses might leave you with the impression that most, if not all, materials are (a) solids and (b) crystalline,  this is plainly untrue.  Milk (a colloid), plastic (a polymer melt), the stuff that covers your cells (a membrane), Sonepat air in November (an aerosol), plasticine (a viscoelastic solid),  oil extraction (fluid in a porous medium), LC displays (nematic liquid crystals), sand piles (granular media), ketchup (a yield stress material) as well as many other examples, are ubiquitous in our daily lives. But these are neither solid nor crystalline. Instead they flow,  respond in non-linear ways to perturbations and organize in fascinating and unexpected ways.

What ideas might unite such disparate phenomena? I will concentrate on the importance of thermal fluctuations and Brownian motion, the relevance of entropy, ideas of scaling behaviour, coarse-grained models, emergence, phase transitions, ideas of renormalization and the importance of topological defects.

I plan to cover (most of) the following:

1) Introduction to soft condensed matter: Length, time and energy scales, diffusion and related properties, examples, stress tensor, basics of statistical mechanics

2) Fluids and their description, viscosity

3)  Colloids and their interactions

4) What is measured, scattering experiments, response and correlation functions

5) Polymer physics, random and self-avoiding walks, polymer solutions, phase separation, biological examples

6) Liquid crystals: nematics, smectics, cholesterols and discotics

7) Membranes, curvature elasticity, osmotic pressure, measurements

8) Dynamical properties: fluctuation dissipation relation, response functions, viscoelasticity

9) Special topics: Granular media, active systems, glasses

Learning Outcomes

At the end of this course, you will have a overall broad view of this field and the ability to understand what's interesting and current, in addition to being able to carry out  basic and intermediate-level calculations.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended background reading, but I will teach most of what I require in class.

1) Soft Matter Physics: Masao Doi

2) Principles of Condensed Matter Physics by P. M. Chaikin, T. C. Lubensky

3) Scaling Concepts in Polymer Physics by Pierre Gilles de Gennes

4) Structured fluids by Thomas Witten

5) Fluid Mechanics: Course of Theoretical Physics - Vol. 6 by Lev Landau

 

Grading Rubric

I plan to centre evaluations around daily in-class-quizzes, an end-term project  and final presentation. The quizzes will count for most of the grade: 70% and the end-term project and presentation will take up the rest.

Attendance Policy

Overview

About the course:

Chemistry teaches the art of creating new molecules, new materials, compounds that never existed. In most cases to meet the demands, industry level synthetic production of the naturally occurring materials such as various polymers or drugs, is required. Everything around us is a product of some sort of chemical reaction.  

This course offers an introductory level understanding of various processes that take place in organic chemical reactions. Course structure is designed to refresh your chemistry knowledge from your school and to prepare you for your journey towards becoming an expert. It will provide better understanding of all the key concepts that you may require to solve the puzzles of chemical bonding and reactions.

The world of chemistry, and especially organic chemistry, might look scary. However, if fundamental rules and some basic principles are understood, most things start becoming obvious events. Concept of electronegativity, resonance, conjugation, hybridisation, steric effects, and aromaticity are key in explaining the number of complexities found organic chemistry.  

The first question that one might ask is why atoms form molecules, and once they have come close to each other, what keeps them intact. What are the factors that decide the path and the fate of any chemical reaction? The purpose of this course is to make sure that your journey into the realm of organic reactions and all those rule exceptions is more enjoyable!

Course Contents/Topics:

Stereochemistry of simple straight chain and cyclic alkanes

  • Conformational nomenclature: eclipsed, staggered, gauche, syn and anti; dihedral angle, torsion angle
  • Energy barrier of rotation and relative stability of conformers
  • Conformational analysis of ethane, propane, n-butane, and 2-methylbutane; cyclohexane and cyclopentane
  • Geometrical isomerism: cis–trans, syn-anti, and E/Z notations with C.I.P rules.

Organic Acids and Bases

  • Hybridisation, Inductive effects, Hyperconjugation, Mesomeric effects, and Steric effect and their effect on acidity/basicity
  • Concept of pKa and pKaH, effect of structure, substituent and solvent on acidity and basicity; proton sponge

Addition and Elimination Reactions

  • Elimination reactions: formation of alkenes and alkynes; mechanisms, reactivity, regioselectivity and stereoselectivity
  • Addition Reactions of alkenes and alkynes: Mechanism, reactivity, regioselectivity (Markownikoff and anti-Markownikoff addition) and stereoselectivity

Interconversion of functional groups

  • Oxidation of alcohols to form aldehyde/ketone & carboxylic acids
  • Oxidation and reduction of aldehydes to form carboxylic acids & alcohols
  • Conversion of carboxylic acid into acid chlorides, esters, amides and reduction to alcohols

 

Learning Outcomes
  • Students will develop understanding about the factors that make an organic compound acidic or basic. Strength of organic acids and bases will be studied in details.    
  • Electronic and steric factors basically control the behavior of a molecule in any chemical reaction. A clear understanding of electronic and steric effects enables us to predict several chemical properties. 
  • Will study the fact that why some system exists in a particular conformation. What makes a specific geometric arrangement more stable than the other. 
  • Addition and elimination reactions will be studied.
  • Will learn the various oxidation & reduction reactions that lead to inter-conversion of various functional groups such as alcohol to aldehyde or acid etc.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  • Organic Chemistry by Jonathan Clayden, Nick Greeves and Stuart Warren.
  • Advanced Organic Chemistry: Part A: Structure and Mechanisms by Francis A. Carey and Richard J. Sundberg.
  • Interested in studying more about atomic orbitals: Principles of Atomic Orbitals by N. N. Greenwood
  • Organic Chemistry by Morrison & Boyd.
  • Organic Chemistry, Vol-1, by I L Finar.

courseTitle: Figure Drawing as Remembering and Reimagining
description:
Figure Drawing as Remembering and Reimagining [VA-2016] [VA-2016-1]

Faculty Name
Anni Kumari [anni.kumari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Title of the Course: Figurative Drawing

Level of the Course: 2000, 3000,

Prerequisites: None

Course Description: In Western academic art education, figurative drawing was until recently considered the foundation, the essential prerequisite for mastering disciplines of painting, sculpture, frescos, and murals. Although it is no longer a requisite skill for contemporary artists, a high proportion would still agree that irrespective of whatever material they might choose to work in, they ‘think’ in terms of drawings. Drawing is more than simply a skill in that it offers a path to self-discovery, revealing a cast of mind, an imaginative capacity, and a mode of perception.

This course encourages students to re-think and re-imagine the human body beyond a representational image, as an entity with constant trans-mutative possibilities regarding form, functionality, and aesthetics. Through a combination of practice and discourse, the course encourages explorations beyond human anatomy by focusing on the varied manifestations and meanings ascribed to the human figure, vis-à-vis the body, in the context of visual art and beyond.

Students will be introduced to contemporary artistic practices and deliberations on artistic visions, experiences, and wisdom that push the boundaries of accepted notions of ‘high’ art and critique hierarchies of attitude. Tracing the history of figure drawing as a genre that goes back to Classical antiquity to the Italian Renaissance, extending into the 18th-century French academia and the 19th-century Victorian Era, students will get a broad overview of how the established notion of accuracy and idealized beauty continues to be challenged and reinvented as artists take on a variety of approaches to drawing the human figure. 

The course looks at how the idealized notion of body is challenged and replaced with bodies that are bruised, grotesque, and out of proportion with visible stretch marks, skin hair, wrinkles, and pigmentation. How has the conscious shift towards drawing from memory and imagination as opposed to drawing from a live model or from photographic references allowed artists to create works that are often loaded with political commentary and emotive power?

In this course, students have the flexibility to work with both analog and digital mediums and materials enabling them to connect to their context, concerns, and interests with a sense of immediacy by using the human figure as a trigger.

The frameworks we will be working through the course include:

  • Understanding the various kinds of representations of the human figure - from different social and cultural contexts. Locating discursive modes of representation.
  • Probing ideas of beauty, identity, sexuality, and gender, through human form.
  • Understanding space-time and memory in the context of the human body and its representation.
  • Exploring the human figure in contemporary drawings under the broad categorizations of the body, self, personal lives, social reality, and fiction.
  • Reflecting on processes of overlapping, erasures, and incision as acts layered with emotive and intuitive sensibilities.
  • Developing an individual methodology /strategy for figurative drawing.

The course will unfold over three modules; each spread over four weeks respectively, and will include both theoretical readings and practical assignments.  

Module 1

The human figure in visual arts:

A historical perspective, a cultural and social perspective.

Representing human body- a repository of concepts.

Overview- Western naturalism through Renaissance, Human form in Egyptian Drawing, Indian painting and Human form.

Basic observational drawings.

Portraiture and history painting.

The renaissance body- Leonardo, Michelangelo and Raphael, Durer

Representing flesh and desire- Boucher, Ingre, Rubens,

Modernity and Body - Humor, satire and politics of  expressing the Body in painting, sculpture. (Manet, van Gogh, Rodin, Daumier,  

Drawing from archival works,

Conceptualising a space for body – Giorgio de Chirico, Piranesi, Escher,  

Module 2:

Body as a biological entity

Anatomy studies, life drawing, studies in biology and medical discourse.

Triumph of realism in representations of body,

Drawing the body- precision in Biology

Structures of form- synthesizing biological and organic material.

Module 3:

The human figure in Contemporary Art

Body as a Phenomenological Tool

Expressionism, Surrealism, Body and Conceptual Art, Feminism, Neo-expressionism, the Popular

Depictions through drawing and photography, - Ana Mandietta, Janine Antoni,

Body as a performative tool. - Marina Abramovic, Yoko Ono, Rumana Hussain

Depictions through journaling, everyday bodies – Louise Bourgeoise, Chittoprasad, Arpita Singh,

Body as wear and tear, absences, fragmented, diseased – Kiki Smith, Eva Hesse, Anthony Gormley

Body as text and body as material- Jenny Holzer, Nalini Malani, Mithu Sen, Juul Krajer

Body as Monuments of Social Expression. – Doh Ho Suh, Kara Walker, William Kentridge

Learning Outcomes

Learning Objectives: 

The course is expected to make students aware of the significant position of the human figure in art, especially in the context of drawing and conceptualization.

Some of the key concepts on culture and representation will be explored-  realism, mimesis, illustration, and the role of fantasy and memory in the process of artistic production.

Students will learn about fundamental techniques of representation through observation and imaging.

Students will learn processes, mediums, and materials employed by artists, both historically and in contemporary times.

Introduction to Mughal History [HIS-3204/ POL-3056] [HIS-3204/ POL-3056-1]

Faculty Name
Pratyay Nath [pratyay.nath@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Mughal emperors believed that they are the divinely-mandated rulers of the entire universe. This was reflected in their imperial titles like Jahangir (Conqueror of the World), Shah Jahan (King of the World), and Alamgir (Conqueror of the Universe). However, how much power did they actually wield? How did they use paintings and architecture to articulate their grand visions of power? What role did war, diplomacy, ideology, and religion play in the process of imperial expansion? These are some of the questions we will engage with. This course offers a comprehensive introduction to Mughal history and historiography. We will explore how the legacy of Chinghiz Khan and Amir Timur Gurgan shaped the empire in South Asia. We will look into the ideals of masculinity that animated Mughal courtly etiquette and study the role of Mughal women in court society. We will investigate how the empire legitimised its rule, disciplined its elite, and created its fabled riches. Finally, we will study why such a huge and prosperous empire fragmented away in the eighteenth century.

NB: This History elective is corss-listed with Political Science.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the semester, students will have a firm understanding of various facets of the Mughal Empire as well as the myriad ways in which modern scholars have looked at this rich and complex history.

Overview

In this course, you will develop and rehearse the habits that are essential to the development of a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening and - of course - thinking. You will engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding -- of situations, texts, institutions and people. You will explore the distinctness of academic research and writing, and participate in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers. By the close of the course, you will have a clearer understanding of what it means to be a scholar in an academic setting, and a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing.

The theme this semester is Environmentalism Desi-Style where we read writings by Vandana Shiva, Amita Baviskar, Mahesh Rangarajan, Nagaraj Adve, Arpitha Kodiveri,  examine miscellaneous news reports, social media posts, and opinion pieces, and watch short films, videos and reels together to explore how environmentalism might mean different things for different people in South Asia, and how it has different ramifications in our part of the world than it does in the West. 

Most importantly, our classroom will be a safe space for discussion, debate and constructive disagreements. 

I like my classes to be as interactive and discussive as possible. All the same, if you feel unsure or diffident about speaking up in class, please do not worry; there will be many ways in which I can continue to get a sense of how you feel about various things under discussion, via the weekly blog, other written submissions, and our chats during office hours.

Overview

This is a graduate-level econometrics course focusing on causal identification. The course begins with a discussion of the Rubin-Causal model, and randomized controlled trials – the pinnacle for causal econometric designs. Subsequently, it moves to selection on observable designs, and the use of fixed effects to control for select unobservables. The second half of the course focuses on three key empirical techniques for causal identification: namely differences-in-difference, regression discontinuity designs, matching and instrumental variables. The course will focus mainly on the intuition behind causal identification and applying them in practice. A critical component of the course would be reading empirical academic papers. This would provide students with some context in the application of the empirical methods introduced in class. This course will focus on both theoretical knowledge as well as implementation of theory through software applications like STATA and real datasets.

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course students should be able to understand non-experimental methods of impact evluation and apply them to data.

Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-1]

Faculty Name
Bikram Phookun [bikram.phookun@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The principles of science manifest themselves in different ways in different domains of science. In this course we will learn how they do so in astronomy and cosmology, which are different from physics in one fundamental respect: in physics we can do experiments to test our hypotheses, but in astronomy and cosmology we cannot. Fortunately, the fundamental laws of physics, tested through Earth-based experiments, have been applicable to the entire universe since the beginning (so far as we can tell). This point is important because we can see the universe only as it was in the past, since all information-bearing signals — in particular light, the most important of signals — must travel at finite speed. Thus the signals received from an object record not the present but the moment in the past when they were emitted. When combined with the vast distances that separate objects in the universe, this leads to the astonishing conclusion that a deep snapshot of the universe from any point taken “at any moment” is actually a snapshot of the history of the universe. We might ask why information cannot be transmitted instantaneously. The answer is embedded in the fabric of space and time, which is described by Einstein’s special theory of relativity. And the fabric of space and time, we will discover, is modified by the presence of the matter that occupies it. The modification of space and time by matter is the understanding due to Einstein of what we normally call the force of gravity. But of course gravity, as we all know, was first understood by Newton; so we start there.

Newton’s version of gravity correctly describes familiar phenomena like the motion of planets around the Sun. What is less obvious is that gravity can be used to discover planets. This method was first used to discover Neptune, and has been used extensively to discover exoplanets, i.e. planets outside the solar system. In the first part of this course we will figure out how exoplanets can be revealed by Newton’s theory of gravity, and in the process learn how it and physics work. In the second part of the course, we will understand how the nature of space and time results in a maximum speed for all signals. In the third part we will talk briefly about the way in which massive objects, for example black holes, modify the space-time around them. And in the final part we will try to understand how the universe — i.e. space-time with all that it contains — has evolved since the beginning and how it may end. 
 

Learning Outcomes

Learning how science works, and, in the process, learning how amazing our universe is.

Overview

The Planet Earth: Its status in the Universe, potential threats and the ultimate fate

    A formidable combination of astronomical and geological conditions has made it possible for the Earth to harbour life on it. But there are many catastrophic events in the space that may destroy life, even the planet which in the vast cosmic arena appears as a mote of dust suspended in a beam of sunlight and floating in the vast emptiness of space. Search for extra-terrestrial life has taught us an important lesson that our world, mother Earth is an extremely rare place in our galaxy and possibly the only planet that has the required astrophysical and geological conditions for harbouring life. Even if there are other planets similar to the Earth wherein life may exist, the number of such planets in the vast galaxy is extremely small and so we are alone at least within a radius of few hundreds of light years. This course will unfold the fact that our home, the planet Earth is so special yet so vulnerable, so crowded yet so lonely, so common yet so unique, so insignificant yet so great! 

        The following topics will be covered in the whole course: 

(i)    Our address in the Universe, the hierarchy in the structure of the visible Universe – super clusters of galaxies, clusters of galaxies, galaxies, the Milky Way Galaxy, stars: the building blocks of galaxies, The Sun and the Solar System. 

(ii)   Birth of the Sun and its planets including the Earth. A brief history of the solar planets

(iii)  We are made of star dust – the origin of heavy elements including carbon the building block of organic molecules. 

(iv)   Life is a puzzle: Definition of life- its main functions: Metabolism, replication and evolution by natural selection.  Origin of life on the Earth.  

(v)   Evolution of life in a changing Earth – the first, second and the third atmosphere of the Earth, formation of the Oceans, Continents and forest. The ecological system.  

(vi)  The potential threats to the Earth – Astronomical, Geological and Man-made threats.  Extinction of life in the past.

(viii)  Are we alone? Search for extra-terrestrial biosignature and techno-signature. 

(ix)    The evolution of the Sun – from a faint young star to a red giant and a changing environment of the Earth – from habitable to uninhabitable planet. 

(x)     The death of the Sun and the fate of its planets.

Literature and the World [FC-0701] [FC-0701-2]

Faculty Name
Jonathan Gil Harris [jgharris@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This class begins with the premise that every story is a migrant.  A story migrates in a variety of ways – from the teller to the audience or reader; but also from reader to reader, place to place, and culture to culture, as the story gets told and retold (or written and rewritten) over space and time. 

We live in a capitalist age when ideas of private property have subtly colonized how we think about stories.  It is assumed that a story is always BY someone, and is therefore their possession.  But if stories migrate, can a single author really claim full ownership of the story she has written?  How is every story a re-imagining of another story, or many stories, that have become before?

The notion that a story is an author’s private intellectual property also inhibits how we read.  Readers become potential trespassers; they must pay the price of admission, and then act respectfully when they enter the property, making sure not to damage or alter it.  If you are a student of literature, it’s likely that the command to respect an author’s private property will be accompanied by the assumption that the objective of literary analysis is simply to understand what the author intended, and to submit to that deferentially.  But if stories migrate from teller to reader, and from reader to reader and culture to culture, maybe the act of reading should not be thought of just as a respectful encounter with an author’s private property.  Every act of reading instead becomes a creative re-imagining of the story, in conversation with new potential readers and audiences. 

If stories are migrants, then they are no longer individual property by authors who command their readers.  They are collective artefacts that invite us to respond creatively and re-imagine them anew.

If you doubt what I am saying, think this.  Do any two readers respond exactly the same way to a story?  Each reader, when asked about a story and what it meant, will retell it slightly differently.  Recognizing that reading is a form of creative re-imagining is one of this course’s most important themes.

As stories migrate across space, time, and languages, they are re-imagined by the world across many genres and media – poems, plays, novels, essays, films, graphic novels.  These re-imaginings might prove that, in literature, there is nothing original under the sun.  Yet how literature reimagines earlier stories also tells us a lot about the extraordinarily diverse ways in which different cultures have understood the world: relations between men and women, relations between diverse ethnicities and religions, the nature of political and social power, humans’ relations to the animal and plant world, the agonies and ecstasies of love, and the nature of imagination itself. 

How, for example, is a Roman re-imagining of an old Greek story about an Asian witch re-imagined by an English playwright in an “American” drama that has itself been re-imagined in very different ways by writers and artists from the Caribbean, Sierra Leone, Mauritius, and Samoa?  How is a Roman re-imagining of a Babylonian (ie Iraqi) love story reworked by the same English playwright in a Greek mythic tale with an Asian subtext that gets in turn re-imagined by a Bombay director in Hindi, Punjabi, Urdu and English as well as by an English graphic novelist in a reworking of an American comic-book hero’s saga based on a character from a German short story?  And how is an antique Persian story about an African migrant re-imagined in an Arab novel and then re-imagined by the same English playwright, whose play is then diversely re-imagined by a Sudanese novelist and a Hindi film-maker from Uttar Pradesh?

Faculty Name

Overview

Literature and the World: “Dil ki Duniya”

Often defined as the totality of all things in existence, the “world” as a category and as a concept is unique within histories of human thought. For example, in contexts such as “World Affairs,” “World Commerce,” or “World Literature,” we encounter the “world” almost as an adjective that points to a sense of vastness or universality. This sense of immensity is also conveyed in expressions like such and such or so and so, “means the world to me.” Such a usage relates to yet another sense in which one may understand the “world,” and that is as a horizon or locus of one’s individual and shared perceptions and experiences. Extending from such a personal sense of the word and contrary to universality or immensity, an expression like, “You and I come from very different worlds,” expresses a seeming incommensurability across individual and subjective experiences.

In this course we will be working towards understanding this unique and exceptional elasticity of the “world” as an idea or a concept, and as a lived reality through its representations in literature. We will be reading a wide sampling of texts such as Banarasidas’ Ardhakathanak, Albert Camus’ The Outsider, Alice Walker's The Color Purple and Vaikom Muhammad Basheer’s Me Grandad 'ad an Elephant. As we encounter and navigate these fictive and literary worlds, we will also be reflecting on ways in which we understand our place and the place of others in the world(s) that we live in.

GREAT BOOKS: Course Abstract. Monsoon Semester, 2024

It is a truism that words mean something, and that they count for a great deal in life. However, the relation between thought, reality and time has always been a matter of debate. The Greek word theoria meant contemplation, the act of looking, which later acquired the sense of an intelligible explanation based on observation and reasoning. Historia meant inquiry, the search for knowledge; and it evolved over time to mean investigations and accounts of past events. Philosophia meant the love of wisdom. In contrast, sophistry referred to skilful rhetoric, the art of persuasion.

These words, which relate to human experience in its deepest sense, prompt my choice of great books. As to why this is so should become clear in due course.  The books are:

Simon Leys; The Hall of Uselessness: Collected Essays, (2011)

Tibor Szamuely; The Russian Tradition; (1974)

Margaret Chatterjee; Gandhi and the Challenge of Religious Diversity; (2005)

Albert Camus; The Rebel: An Essay on Man in Revolt; (1951)

Mark Lilla; The Reckless Mind: Intellectuals in Politics; (2001)

Stanley Rosen; Nihilism: A Philosophical Essay (1969)

The first three books deal (in part) with history; with what is called tradition; and the treatment of these themes in political writing and fiction. The latter three deal with philosophical issues directly. I will introduce students to these books, and specify certain chapters for required reading. Their scholarship will educate us and prompt us toward further study. Some will illuminate important historical events; others will raise issues common to human experience regardless of time and place.

courseTitle: Futures Perfect - a Literary History of Utopia
description:
Futures Perfect - a Literary History of Utopia [ENG-2105] [ENG-2105-1]

Faculty Name
Alexandra Cassatt Verini [alexandra.verini@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Utopia, etymologically, is “a good place that is nowhere,” but what is it exactly? Is it a mindset, a literary genre, a political philosophy, or something else? Is it a place that we would want to inhabit? Why, despite so often being dismissed as idealistic fantasy, is utopia such an enduring and appealing idea?

Using these questions as starting points, this course offers a theoretical and historical overview of utopian thinking across time and space. We will examine the rise of utopia as a European literary genre by reading Thomas More’s Utopia and Francis Bacon’s New Atlantis alongside canonical theories of utopia by Ernst Bloch and Fredric Jameson. We will connect these early utopias to the later genre of science fiction and speculative fiction as we read works by Ursula LeGuin and Marge Piercy. At the same time, the course complicates this history by examining utopias from before the early modern period (such as the Land of Cockaigne and Christine’s de Pizan’s City of Ladies) as well as those that come from outside a predominantly male and western lineage (Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s Herland and Rokeya Sakhawat Hossain’s The Sultana’s dream). We will conclude by considering utopian thinking beyond the literary in the records of real-world utopias. In our readings and discussions, we will aim not to develop not a single definition of utopia but rather to gain an understanding of the many ways in which utopia (and its seeming opposite dystopia) has and continues to be a vital aesthetic and political tool.

description:

Faculty Name
Kasturi Mitra [Kasturi.mitra@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sougata Roy [sougata.roy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How is an organism’s structure and function regulated? The answer to this question lies within the inherited DNA. Genetics have evolved phenomenally since Mendel first introduced the concept of genes during the mid-1800s. Today genetics is used in all phases of life from food to medicines, new discoveries tend to manipulate genetics not only to diagnose and find better cure for deadly diseases like cancer but also to design smart plants and microbes to enhance the quality and quantity of food and secondary metabolites such as biofuel. Hence a thorough knowledge of genetics is an absolute requirement for biologists to comprehend the complexity of living organisms.

Specifically, you will learn in detail about the structure, function and regulation of chromosomes and genes Variation in phenotype is important for evolution. This is usually accompanied by underlying genetic variation. We will therefore study how genetic variation comes about, and focus on some model organisms used for genetic studies. Subsequently we will learn about the inheritance of complex traits and population genetics. This course will provide basic as well as advanced understanding of the concepts and tools that are used in molecular genetics and molecular biology. Then we will discuss how to evaluate and design key cutting-edge research in the field of molecular biology.

Learning Outcomes

This course will provide a basic understanding of the concepts of molecular biology and build the platform to learn advanced molecular biology approaches and their application. You will learn in detail about the following:

Central dogma of molecular biology and its variations in life.

Structure, function and regulation of chromosomes and genes at the molecular level.

Actions of the core molecular players in DNA replication, gene transcription and mRNA translation, DNA repair and recombination.

Basic principles of gene regulation.

Fundamental of genetic engineering.

Existence of different model organisms and their advantages and disadvantages.

Various tools of gene manipulation.

Introduction to DNA sequencing technologies.

Overview

Have you ever visited a key maker? You must have seen lots of premade keys with unique shapes and sizes. However, only certain keys might work for a particular lock. But what makes a particular key functional for one lock but not for the others? It entirely depends on the structural complementarity of lock and key. Similarly, in Biology, thousands of such keys for specific locks mediate numerous biological functions based on their shapes, features, and their interactions with the surroundings. This course will discuss how these biological keys or biomolecules are structured for their specific functions and various methods to determine the structure and functions of biological macromolecules. Through this course, we will be asking some of these questions.

This is a course where archaeology and science meet in order to reconstruct the human past from the relics of past activities using cool scientific techniques. These relics range from the garbage that people have generated as they have lived their daily lives to deliberate constructions like temples and fortifications. description:
Introduction to Biology II: Cell Biology [BIO-2214] [BIO-2214-1]

Faculty Name
Anup Padmanabhan [anup.padmanabhan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Cells are the fundamental unit of life. It carries out all (well… almost all!) the physiological processes essential for its survival and propagation. Within the cell, each of these processes is accomplished by molecular machines. What are these processes and how do these mini machines come together to carry out cellular functions? How different are these machines in prokaryotic cells and plants ? What drives (physically and figuratively) these cellular machines to the right place at the right time to carry out appropriate functions? What properties emerge when cells co-operate to form tissues?

Learning Outcomes

In this introductory Cell Biology course, essential processes at the cellular level will be explored to understand how molecular machines carry out these processes. The primary focus of this course will be on eukaryotic cells.  There are 3 lectures on prokaryotic cell biology to draw comparisons between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cellular processes to appreciate their similarities and distinctness. By the end of this course,the participant is expected to have a good conceptual grasp of basic cellular mechanisms, the molecular machinery involved, and their functional regulation within a cell. Through detailed discussions on cell biology methods and classical cell biology experiments, the participants should be able to read and interpret experimental data and appreciate the role of controls and able to design cell biology experiments to test hypotheses.

Faculty Name

Overview

Dastangoi, an ancient art of storytelling comprises of Dastans which were epics and were often recited. They were a crucial part of our oral tradition. This extremely popular art of Dastangoi, unfortunately died out with its last traditional proponent Mir Baqar Ali in 1928. Over the last 20 years this artform has seen a major revival thanks to the scholarship of the late S. R. Faruqi and Mahmood Farooqui who have trained dozens in this modern Art form. Through this course we aim to analyse and compare different forms of Dastangoi performances using practical examples. Given the linguistic diversity at Ashoka, we would also like to explore the possibility of Dastangoi beyond Urdu language. The sessions would be interactive, and students will get a chance to work on performative aspects of dastangoi like voice modulation, poetry recitation, pronunciation, expressions. Towards the end, the students will be required to present their learnings on stage.

Along with standard Assamese, the course will also lay emphasis on understanding and appreciating other variants of the language and the cultural and literary produces in them. In addition to being introduced to the wide array of tribal languages in Assam like Bodo, Mising, Karbi and Tiwa, the students will also be made aware of how these languages are - both linguistically and politically - influenced by and coexist with Assamese, the official and commonly-used language of the state. Overview

This course will enable students to understand the role of financial markets and institutions in shaping the economic and business environment of the nation. With the help of some simplifying frameworks and models, the students will be equipped to develop a series of applications of principles from finance and economics that explore the connection between financial markets, financial institutions and the broader economy. Keynesian IS-LM theory and the loanable funds theory provide the theoretical background for the course and help students develop simple analytical frameworks to study the interaction of individuals, firms, governments, markets, financial institutions, and the aggregate economy. The students will get an introduction to the role of regulation in the overall functioning of financial markets and institutions in the economy.

Urban Economics [ECO-3605] [ECO-3605-1]

Faculty Name
Lalit Hemant Contractor [lalit.contractor@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The decision of where to locate is essential for both business and individuals. It determines the profits of firms through the cost of inputs, market size, the level of competition, and the policy environment they face. It also determines the job opportunities, schooling, and other amenities accessible to individuals. In turn, firm and individual decisions aggregate to determine the performance of cities and regions.

This course studies business and individual location decisions and how they determine the main economic forces (agglomeration economies) that lead to the existence and performance of cities and
regional agglomerations. The course starts by developing a simple theory of cities (the monocentric city model) and its implications for density, city size and housing prices. We will study the internal structure of cities by introducing the key notion of spatial equilibrium, and then evaluate the effects of land use policies, different means of transportation and infrastructure and housing policies on land and housing values. We shall also consider spatial equilibrium across a region using the framework of Rosen and Roback.

We shall also briefly consider the empirical literature that seeks to test some of the theories developed. Other topics that will be covered, time permitting, include urban governance, urban growth and decline and more
local aspects such as neighbourhood choice and gentrification. Finally, the course will analyze cities in the developing world, and conclude with recent advances in the field.

Learning Outcomes

Students should gain an understanding of the forces that drive the formation of cities and the patterns of location and prices within cities. They should be familiar with the basic models and empirical approaches developed for these purposes, which provide a conceptual framework for thinking about topics in the field.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Lecture slides and links to reading materials shall be provided on the course website.

I shall base the lecture materials on the text, 'Lectures on Urban Economics' by Jan Brueckner (MIT Press/Prentice Hall India). I shall also draw upon the text, 'Urban Economics and Fiscal Policy' by Holger Sieg (Princeton University Press).

Monetary Theory [ECO-3200] [ECO-3200-1]

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What exactly is "money"? Is it simply something that we needed for trading? If so, then money would be a constraint - a thing without which trades can't happen. What about alternative trading arrangements like barter or credit? Why is barter, credit, or a system that keeps track of transfers, inferior to money? Why is fiat money Pareto superior to commodity money (gold, silver, etc.)? What causes inflation? What about banking - why do we need it? Are banks always welfare-improving? Why do banks fail? This course starts with a micro-founded approach to money using an overlapping generations model and discusses why money is not a constraint but an instrument that arises endogenously leading to welfare gains for the economy. Then we build on this model and go on to study the relationship between money and other institutions that issue/ use money - financial intermediation & banks, a model of bank risk and bank panic (Diamond-Dybvig model).

Time permitting and based on your collective interest & my expertise, we might cover other interesting topics in monetary economics such as national debt, fiscal theories of price level & inflation, pension systems, and/ or one or two MA/ Ph.D. level papers on money-related topics.
