Decision Theory [ECO-6105] [ECO-6105-1]

Faculty Name
Abhinash Borah [abhinash.borah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We will focus on three prominent areas of decision-theoretic research: (i) theories of behavioral choices; (ii) decisions under uncertainty; and (iii) stochastic choices;

For the first topic, we will begin by setting up the foundations of rational choice theory and then look at the case against it. We will focus on a set of topics that will respond to rational choice theory’s descriptive (and at times normative) limitations. Amongst them will be prospect theory and the theme of reference-dependent preferences; sequential choice procedures featuring multiple rationales; choice theories featuring limited consideration; theories of temptation and self-control. 

For the second topic, we will examine the foundations of subjective probabilities and Bayesianism. We will study the classic approaches of De Finetti, Savage, and Anscombe-Aumann to this question. After that, we will focus on the large and impressive literature on decision-making under ambiguity that has emerged in the last three decades or so. Ambiguity, here, refers to decision settings in which a decision-maker perceives “uncertainty about probability, created by missing information that is relevant and could be known” (Frisch and Baron, 1988). That such decision settings exist was pointed out by Ellsberg (1961). His work showed how ambiguity represents a normative criticism of the subjective expected utility framework of Savage (1954) and, by extension, of the Bayesian paradigm. David Schmeidler’s work in the late 1980s revived interest in this area of research. We will cover important models like Schmeidler’s Choquet expected utility, Gilboa and Schmeidler’s maximin expected utility, Klibanoff, Marinacci, and Mukerji’s smooth ambiguity model, and Siniscalchi’s vector expected utility. Before getting to all this, though, we will first look at a few landmark models of decision-making under risk like vNM expected utility and rank-dependent utility. 

For the third topic, we will look at the Luce model and its generalizations, random utility and random expected utility model, and random consideration models.

courseTitle: Visual and Material Cultures of the Himalayas
description:
Visual and Material Cultures of the Himalayas [VA-2006/ SOA-2215/ MS-3098] [VA-2006/ SOA-2215/ MS-3098-1]

Faculty Name
Latika Gupta [latika.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Level: 1000/ 2000/ 3000

Prerequisites: None

This course focuses on the Western Himalayas to understand how visual and material cultures are intrinsically connected with the idea of ‘place’. We will look at how places, cultures and people are constructed through representations — visual and written — both by ‘outsiders’ as well as local communities. Utilising interdisciplinary methodologies borrowing from visual anthropology, material culture studies, museology and history, students will engage with critical questions about the ethics of representation in imaging ‘other’ places and people, the socio-political processes that inform the making of tradition, and the entanglements of politics and culture in the formation of regional and national identities.

We will read a contemporary novel, early travel accounts, do a deep dive into colonial and contemporary photography, watch films and look at representations in popular culture. Through field visits to a Tibetan exile settlement and a museum in Delhi, we will study material culture in relationship to its uses and the recontextualization of sacred objects within museum spaces.

Some of the questions we will explore include: How are cultures constructed through acts of museumisation? How did the field of ‘Himalayan Art’ emerge? Where do we ‘locate’ this field; which geographical areas and religions are made emblematic of this discipline; which cultures are excluded and why? How were museum collections built and in what historical circumstances? What curatorial strategies are used to reconstruct the auras of objects? How are sacred objects of use segregated into categories of art and ethnography?

We will also examine the recent museum-making impulse in the Himalayas through case studies of a range of museums situated in these borderlands — war memorial museums, community museums of conflict and trade route artefacts, and museums in Buddhist monasteries to understand the relationship between heritage and religion, the impact of the movement of things from sacred sites to ‘secular’ museums, and to ask how a politics of remembrance may manifest in cultural production. The course will conclude with an introduction to Tibetan/ Buddhist culture-in-exile through contemporary Tibetan art, poetry, writing and films.

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students:
• will be familiar with the broad field of the visual and material cultures in the Western Himalayas in Tibet, Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh.
• will learn about major museums and collections of Himalayan Art and be able to critically analyze the framing of objects as art or ethnography, and questions of provenance research and label writing in object displays.
• will be conversant with critical questions around heritage, the politics of museums and the role of tradition in the construction of contemporary cultural identities.
• will acquire the critical tools interrogate the nature and impact of ‘representation’ of regions, cultures and communities through images and written texts.
• will be able to analyse and read images and texts, with a focus on meaning making through vocabularies and terminologies, and apply this critical thinking in a curatorial project.

Overview

 

Economics, Politics and Society

The New Political: Reconfiguring the Human and the Non-Human

Inquiries into science studies, animal rights, and climate change are building up the foundations of a ‘new political’ in our times. Current theorizing and the charge of the ‘new political’ is co-evolving with capitalism as it intensifies its extractive relationship to nature. The planet can well do without us humans; rather it is our survival that is contingent both on living and non-living nature.

We now seek to remake the political by postulating rights of non-human nature, deliberating the agency of matter and reckoning with precarity as the earth’s present condition. The ongoing attempts at reforming politics are not without ifs and buts... and so we shall look into the continuing force of inclusions by legacy and troubling exclusions.

Overview

Why do we think and act the way we do? Why do we believe in a certain moral framework, dream, desire, sleep, work, or eat the way we do? These may seem like the most banal set of questions, prompting a ‘that is just how it is’ response. However, implicated in their answers are hundreds of years of social, economic, and political thought. In this course, we will engage with different social, political, and economic ideas that have changed the way we look and interact with the world, and for this purpose, we will go straight to the horse’ mouth. In other words, we will read and engage with texts written by some of the greatest social, economic, and political thinkers from around the world such as Marx, Ambedkar, Berger & Luckmann, Weber, bell hooks, and Foucault. The only precondition for the course is that students should be willing to engage with the texts.

Economy, Politics and Society [FC-0412] [FC-0412-6]

Faculty Name
Chitralekha Dhamija [chitralekha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Media and Democracy

Is there a straightforward relationship between proliferation of media and democracy? Does freedom for media necessarily mean democratic freedom? What if free media translates into corporatized control over media platforms, algorithms, content, eventually publics themselves? How do we reconcile the rise of digital technologies that evoke narratives of emancipation, autonomy, and freedom- with the simultaneous rise of online troll cultures, virulent racism, sexism, xenophobia, and exclusionary political ideologies around the globe? Answers to questions such as these depend, to begin with, on how we approach understandings of media, democracy, or freedom. 

We will think about mediation as social process that extends beyond ‘the media’- not as power emanating from specific objects, technologies, or institutional practices, but as the ideological foundation of social life. We explore the relationships of media with electoral democracy and its political institutions, but also what they mean for ordinary people outside of its formal and elite institutions: their local meanings and practices, contestations and shifting forms of power, and the multiplicity of desires they both produce and represent. Towards these objectives, we examine actions of governments that relate to repression of media and democratic freedoms- and the struggles to liberate them; but also, how mor­ally loaded concepts such as `freedom’ are given particular meanings in their discourses and social practices. 

The challenge in this course will be to both apprehend the dominant configurations of `media’ and `democracy’ in present times, as well as anticipate imaginations of their possible forms and praxis that might provide for a more diverse and equal world.

Overview

In this course we will learn College level Calculus which starts with learning about infinite collections of numbers, their properties and associate some properties with them.  We will use these to talk about functions that are continuous, differentiable and look at various properties of such functions.  We will then move on to adding up infinitely many numbers, when we can do such an addition and then learn about integrals and their properties. 

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course a student would be comfortable talking about sequences, adding up infinitely many numbers when that is possible,  find out what is meant by a continuous function and how to check if a function is continuous and identify a large class of such functions.  Then, they will also learn about the rate at which the values, of a differentiable function, come close to each other when the points at which the function is evaluated are brought close together.   They will also learn about areas under curves and how they are related to adding up infinitely many numbers.   

In the process they will learn about the possible values a continuous function should take, identify the points where a function reaches its maximum or minimum value and learn about average values of functions and how all these concepts are used in pratical problems.

Short Description of the Course

This course foregrounds some of the critical environmental challenges, by addressing them through diverse ideas and systems of governance. Focusing on environmental governance, it draws its connections with politics, policies, laws, institutions, civil society organisations and environmental movements. The course covers the evolution of various governance systems and their present status, the debates and contests around them, and the emergence of new ideas and mechanisms to govern the use of natural resources through sustainability, justice and equality. It takes a micro and macro, sectorial and broader, and a local and global view, to understand the complex and wide nature of environmental governance in India. With case studies from government and non-government sectors, civil society organisations, and movement groups in different spaces, locations and times, the course explains environmental management and regulation in theoretical and practical terms. Dealing with questions of forests, water, gender, adivasis and climate change, the course encompasses concepts, debates, policies, practices, methods and tools of environmental governance.

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. courseTitle: Nation and State-Making in India's Borders
description:
Nation and State-Making in India's Borders [POL-2067] [POL-2067-1]

Faculty Name
Kaustav Dhar Chakrabarti [kaustav.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Nation and State-Making in India’s Borders examines four key concepts - nation, state, violence, and development - in the context of India’s contested border regions. It is motivated by a set of perplexing observations about armed conflict in India. First, India’s response to civil wars (or insurgencies) involves both massive levels of violence to coerce communities into obedience, and extensive distribution of development funds to induce loyalty. Do these strategies complement or contradict each other? What is the long-term effect of these strategies? 

Second, India has an impressive track record in defeating armed groups, but it struggles to resolve conflicts. Regions like Kashmir, Nagaland, and Manipur continue to remain affected by low levels of violence. Why? 

Third, India’s governing institutions do not fritter away. Generally, we do not notice a complete breakdown of law and order that often leads to large-scale migration in other countries. Instead, civil administration remains robust and even expands during civil wars. How does India succeed in avoiding the World Bank’s conflict-trap hypothesis, wherein armed conflict depletes state’s capacity and creates conditions for future conflict? 

Fourth, even as India limits fundamental rights (such as right to assembly, right to speech and opinion) through the Armed Forces Special Powers Act time and again, it is eager to resume electoral democracy. Why? Why not just continue with the President’s Rule? From Kashmir to Nagaland, elections in conflict zones register exceptionally high participation. Yet, contrary to the convention that voting is an indicator of legitimacy, surveys and ethnographies show that communities affected by conflict do not positively associate with Indian identity, or at the very least, their identification with Indian nationalism is tenuous. How do democratic institutions operate in conflict zones where political rights are limited by the threat of violence by both sides? 

To understand these seemingly contradictory observations, one must look beyond the literature on civil war. The course, therefore, is a compliment to Militants or Freedom Fighters? Armed Conflicts in India (familiarity with the civil war literature is not essential to understand content in Nations..) that examines civil wars in India through the lens of major works of civil wars. Nation and State-Making in India’s Borders will use canonical works of nationalism, state formation, organised violence, and the politics of development as pillars to guide our search for answers to these vexing questions. Equipped with the knowledge of theory, we will study detailed case studies and collectively discuss the most convincing explanations for patterns of nation and state-making in India’s contested borderlands.     

Learning Outcomes

The goals of the course are three-fold. By the end of the course, students should have an overview of some of the major debates in the political science of nation and state-making (or state-formation). We will collectively grapple with understanding linkages between state and nation-making with civil wars. In doing so, the course will also familiarise students with major civil wars (or ‘insurgencies’) in India through detailed case studies. Finally, the course will reinforce the department’s continuous training in analytical thinking. It will bolster students’ ability to distinguish between different theoretical explanations, evaluate the merit of competing arguments made in the literature, and communicate their arguments clearly in written form. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading Guide

Bennet’s chapter explains case studies as a method to generate and test theories.  Finish with a short video that explains Weber’s concept of the Ideal Type.

Class 5: Nation, Nationalism, Nation-Making

Introduction to Political Theory [POL-1009] [POL-1009-1]

Faculty Name
Sushmita Nath [sushmita.nath@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Politics makes appeal to ideas and ideals. These ideas and ideals are expressed through concepts, such as liberty, justice, democracy, nationalism, constitutionalism, secularism, and the like. Political concepts, therefore, mediate our understanding and representation of reality. At the same time, concepts also get rearticulated in the process of this interaction with socio-political reality. While political concepts shape and in turn are shaped by social reality, they also develop and therefore are placed within a larger theoretical field of political theory. Political theory is the sub-field of political science. Because understanding political concepts and ideas are important to study politics, students studying political science should take at least one course in political theory.

There are two main approaches to political theory: history of political thought, which studies the development and history of ideas; and political philosophy, which studies political ideas systematically. Students can meet their political theory requirement through a course in either of the traditions. Introduction to Political Theory focuses on political philosophy, although we will also read some texts which make reference to historical ideas from both Europe and India.

The course is divided into four big parts: i) Democracy and Constitutionalism; ii) Liberalism and Secularism; iii) Social Justice; iv) Nationalism. We begin by studying democracy and constitutionalism. Is there a will of the people? Is democracy possible? Is constitutionalism a compromise with democracy? Constitutionalism is often associated with liberalism and secularism. The second part discusses these ideas. What is the basis for human rights? How should we understand secularism? Do liberty and equality conflict? This last question points towards another domain of politics: social justice. In the third part we look more closely at social justice. We look at questions of caste, class, and gender. Some of these questions are often framed as identity politics. If identity politics draws attention to our immediate or primordial identities, such as caste and gender, how do we understand larger identities, such as nationalism and cosmopolitanism? The fourth and the last section on nationalism draws attention to such issues. In this course students will thus engage with political concepts by studying the various ways in which ideas and politics shape and in turn are shaped by political concepts.

Environmental Economics [ECO-3700] [ECO-3700-1]

Faculty Name
Kavita Sardana [kavita.sardana@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The first part of the course will focus on showing how neoclassical welfare theory forms the basis of the normative criteria that are used to distinguish market and policy-influenced outcomes for the provision of environmental goods and services. From a theoretical perspective, most contemporary topics in environmental economics characterize the failure of the first welfare theorem, missing markets, externalities, and the nature of public goods in the provision of environmental goods. In this context, the interventionist approach using the Pigouvian paradigm, in contrast to the non-interventionist Coasian paradigm will be discussed to achieve efficient allocation of resources. Additionally, a simple analytical model describing pollution damages in monetary units, the cost of pollution prevention, and the characteristics of an efficient allocation of pollution emissions will be used to describe the menu of environmental policy instruments (such as tradable permit schemes) and their comparative properties. Lastly, we will focus on the role of uncertainty in terms of regulator’s inability to fully observe aggregate pollution damage and abatement cost functions, i.e., these functions are estimated by the regulator (inevitably with error) and its extent to influence the performance of different regulatory approaches.

The second part of the course will focus on conceptual and pragmatic understanding in discussing the current dialogue on environmental protection and restoration. Mass movement following the constitution of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the formal meeting of the UNFCC parties (Conference of the Parties, COP) for environmental protection (based on the targets of adaptation and financing) is anchored in the understanding of environmental valuation techniques that provide input into national accounts and policy reforms that are required to channel funds for environmental protection. The focus will be on learning the environmental valuation techniques in general and revealed preference methods and stated preference methods in particular. Practicals in the second part of the course will be conducted with datasets from the field of environmental valuation with the learning objectives and outcomes of making the students adept at using valuation techniques. The analysis will be conducted using STATA software.

Learning Outcomes

1. To understand the application of micro-economic theory in issues relating to environment.

2. To empirically estimate value of  environmental goods and services for benefit-cost analysis.

2. To understand the current policy dialogue on environmental issues.

Monetary Theory [ECO-6200] [ECO-6200-1]

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We start the course by asking a fundamental question: what is money and why is it essential? We will begin with a simple overlapping generations (OLG) model where intrinsically worthless objects are valued at equilibrium. This is fiat money.

After this, we will quickly graduate to the Lagos-Rocheteau-Wright (LRW) class of models a.k.a. New Monetarist models, and use them to understand different aspects of monetary economies and how a monetary economy interacts with other markets – labor markets, asset markets, and over-the-counter (OTC) markets. Time permitting, we will also study Choi and Rocheteau (2021) models which are continuous time versions of LRW models and yield richer dynamics.

In the last phase of the course, we will discuss selected papers on important and interesting issues in monetary economics. Some of these might be “current issues”, while the rest are perennial questions. Students taking the course must select a paper from a predefined list and present it in class. The presentation will be followed by a Q&A.

 I will teach selected chapters from the book Money, Payments, and Liquidity (MIT Press) by Rocheteau and Nosal. This is a graduate textbook on LRW models.

  • Payments on Digital Platforms: Resilience, Interoperability and Welfare by Jonathan Chiu and Russell Wong. Journal of Economic Dynamics and Control (Forthcoming)
  • Search and the market for ideas, by Rafael Silveira and Randy Wright. Journal of Economic Theory (2010)
  • Venture capital: A model of search and bargaining, by Rafael Silveira and Randy Wright. Review of Economic Dynamics (2016)
  • Innovation and growth with financial, and other frictions, by Randy Wright, Jonathan Chiu and Cesaire Meh. International Economic Review (2017)

Grading Rubric

This course is an MA/ PhD Elective. At this stage of education, participation in class and engagement with the course is both expected and desired of you. You are all grown-ups, ready to face the world - I shouldn't have to coax and cajole you to come to class or encourage you to study. In this course, I will be more of a guide by the side than a sage on the stage. I will teach you some seminal models and how certain aspects of monetary economies can be analyzed through the lens of these models, but the rest is up to you to discover. I will give you a map and you need to explore yourself. You will be evaluated under the following heads:

  • Participation (20%): The expectation is that you will attend lectures regularly (and on time), pay attention to what is being taught, and ask pertinent questions. Before coming to class you should study the things covered in the last few lectures. Paper presentations – everyone should read the papers and not just the presenters. During paper presentations, you should ask reasonable questions based on the paper.
  • Homeworks and Class Tests (40%): While teaching, I will at times skip some of the mathsy details and simply present the results. It is your job to do all the math/ derivations/ diagrams and convince yourself of the results. Sometimes I will assign these “filler” derivations/ math/ diagrams as your homework. Sometimes I will assign end-of-chapter questions as homework. Sometimes I will give you short, straightforward class tests based on the material taught the week before.
  • Paper presentation (30%): You will select a paper from a list and present it in class.
  • Research Proposal (10%): 10% might not look much, but I will thoroughly and critically evaluate your proposal. A poorly done, last-minute proposal will earn an inopportune score. Also, a good research proposal distinguishes you from others.

There are no midterms or final exams. However, if I do not see adequate participation and engagement from your side, I will change the evaluation criterion and you will be evaluated under the following heads: HW & Class Tests (10%), Midterm (30%), Final (30%), Paper Presentation (20%), Research Proposal (10%).

Overview

Course Title: Technology in Art: From New Media to the NFTs (Non-fungible Tokens)

Course Instructor: Srinivas Aditya Mopidevi

Level of the Course: Undergraduate / Graduate

This course focuses on the relationship between technology and art from the New Media Art of the 1990s to the present global circulation of digital artworks registered as non-fungible tokens (NFTs). New Media Art that emerged in the wake of digital technology expanded the scope of artistic practice whilst being critical to the technologies it was mobilizing. Art in the time of the NFTs turned artworks into digital assets transacted predominantly through crypto and registered on a decentralized global network ledger called the blockchain. Mapping art’s integral relationship with technology this course will unpack the diverse trajectories of video, new media, and digital art forms that disrupted the clean categories of traditional art history. Further, it will investigate the economic dimensions that accompany the proliferation of digital assets discussing whether the emergence of the NFTs as a registering standard positioned art as an alibi to normalize crypto as a global tender.

The course begins by discussing the history of video art, from the early experiments of Nam June Paik to the immersive installations of Bill Viola, including seminal instances such as the Vision Exchange Workshop that led pioneering Indian artists Akbar Padamsee and Nalini Malani to explore the potentiality of video and animation. Drawing from the work of Ravi Sundaram, it will also discuss the proliferation of video and mobile phone technology across the Global South and how it transformed cultural production and consumption.  

The course will also map the artistic responses to the internet & digital surveillance technology through the practices of Antoni Muntadas, Jodi Brothers, Rafael Lozano-Hemmer, Trevor Paglen, CAMP (Mumbai), Hito Steyerl, Shilpa Gupta, Raqs Media Collective, and others. Further, it will introduce students to contemporary art practices driven by artificial intelligence including Refik Anadol, Entangled Others Studio, and Pindar Var Arman. 

Followed by a detailed analysis of the seminal practices in the history of technology and art, the course also critically engages with the economic and ecological implications of NFTs on contemporary art.

Course Modules: Each session of the course will include a theoretical component and a practical component, which will familiarize the students with the history of technology and art as well as, facilitate hands-on engagement with the digital artworks.

Overview

Visual Storytelling [VA-2010/ MS-1081] [VA-2010/ MS-1081-1]

Faculty Name: Vishwajyoti Ghosh [vishwajyoti.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ;

Overview

VISUAL STORYTELLING: Through Graphic and Sequential Narratives

Why tell stories visually

As the world’s reading engagement is rapidly shrinking into a palm sized mobile, the engagement with the visual is rapidly becoming the new language, with the binaries between the texts and visuals fading away. In these times visual storytelling is making a strong space for itself in every form of information or content. Be it journalism, health information, economics or plain fiction, the visual approach is now here to stay, in an age where the best of storytelling, poetry, journalism or reportage are now visually led.

Visual Storytelling is an ever-evolving medium. From the cave drawings documenting the hunter’s life or the Egyptian clay tablets that documented the Pharaoh’s philosophy or the Persian miniatures that visually documented the Ruler’s court or the wars, the Pahadi miniatures that visually articulated the leelas of Radha Krishna to the visual documentation in the modern era, from the peasant sketches of Van Gogh, the daily life depicted by Seurat, Degas and more or the nightlife by Lautrec, the Mexican muralists like Deigo Rivera, Orzoco, Chittoprasad, Indian artists like Ram Kinkar Baij, Somenath Hore to the best graphic narratives of our times by Chris Ware, Satrapi, Joe Sacco and now to the world of You Tube and Tik Tok animations the form has only grown both in terms of practice but also viewership and acceptance. In the visual world we live now, it is a form with a moving language now blending with technology. This course will blend these influences into ones’ own practice to create comics and graphic narratives in sync with the practitioner’s area of interest and discipline.

This is not to say that all human centric works of art can be categorized as narrative artworks but graphic narratives have grown and imbibed many of these experiences in the making of graphic stories including films and popular culture. For a medium as absorbent as graphic storytelling, the form has drawn inspiration and acknowledged the same from multiple disciplines like painting, prose and poetry, filmmaking and even gaming. It’s this multi-disciplinary influence and framework this course seeks to work with.

Graphic narratives can never be limited to a category but more than a form it has evolved to a medium that has embraced every subject which makes it a complete storytelling tool than an only entertainment or an informational one. 

This course seeks to engage with this fast-moving genre of visual storytelling through comics and graphic narratives with a research led and inter-disciplinary approach, in sync with the student’s core area of interest or discipline.

What this course is about

In sync with the time’s media or information dissemination, it is important to learn and practice visual storytelling as both a language and a medium that can be incorporated in one’s individual academic discipline. This approach can help the students in articulating their learnings, research and storytelling in multi-disciplinary formats that is much required in today’s realm of information & content, where visual storytelling is an alternate and a popular form of information, opinion and communication.

Learning Objectives:

The semester will be a sequential flow from the history of visual documentation and articulation to the modern practices of graphic novels, mobile cartoons, comic strips and now visual narratives on the mobile to a practice- based approach.

In the fast-moving visual world, students will learn to negotiate between the visuals and the written word in the process of crafting their individual narratives. The students will also explore and practice the modes and methods of visual storytelling through their chosen styles and influences. The expected outcome for the students will be practice based learning to develop their visual storytelling language, exploring the fluid connections between fact and fiction.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes:

The preliminary module of this course of 2 weeks will be a curated overview of the published, popular and the prevalent and emerging forms of visual storytelling in the world of graphic narratives and visuals. The idea would be exploring the diversity of practice across the globe and the processes involved in the making. The core idea here will be to discuss the forms and works to bring new practice-based influences and ideas, their working process and explore the architecture of visual storytelling in these works.

Weeks 1-2: Discuss works of art, graphic novels, cartoons, comic strips and create short narratives.

This will be a presentation and discussion-based approach discussing the presented works in detail and the stories behind making many of these works. The idea will be to discuss the journey of the works from the intent to execution and the struggles and transformations that make the narrative in the final output. For example, Van Gogh’s study of the peasantry, the sketch book notes leading to the potato eaters or Somenath Hore’s diaries documenting the Tebhaga movement or Marjane Satrapi’s background story behind the making of Persepolis or Chris Ware’s documentation of the American Midwest are some of the well-articulated stories in the making of these works.

Weeks 3-5: Ideate, research, explore graphic storytelling ideas and create micro books, zines etc.

This will be followed by 3 weeks to ideate, research, explore ideas of student’s interest in their areas of discipline followed by field work, data collection and research on the ground. This will include visual data collection, interviews, recording, documentation and conceptualizing the idea based on the research.

This will lead to create micro books, zines etc.

Documentation of the research will be followed to process and distill the findings to create the core conceptual idea and be presented in the studio sessions for the benefit of collective brainstorming and discussions. These discussions with fellow classmates will led to an inter-disciplinary ideation and conceptualization, moving closer to shape and sharpen the core project ideas of the students. The students will also be expected to share the processing of their research findings along with their influences and inspirations.

Weeks 6-7: Exploring possibilities of form, conceptualization, layout, architecture etc. and presentation of a final project idea followed by discussion on similar ideas & influences

Moving on from research the course will discuss the working process of creating a visual narrative using multiple influences of form and genres. This will include detailed discussions on the various possibilities of the form i.e. different forms that can be explored -doodle narratives, popular comics, mobile based narratives, photo comics, design, layouts, page architecture, typography, sequential storytelling and the work process involved in each, enabling the students to make informed choices in sync with their ideas.

Week 8: Presentation of a final project idea followed by discussion on similar ideas & influences

The following week the students will be expected to present their ideas and preliminary drafts as scribbles/ sketches with fellow batchmates, followed by open discussions, suggestions and ideation to evolve a clear understanding to flesh out the final narrative.

Each student/ project will be further exposed to similar works through display and in-depth discussions on influences and ideas related to the project to lend a visual and storytelling perspective, enabling the practitioner to take one’s work further.

Besides creating multiple micro narratives through the semester, finally, the semester will move to its last weeks to create a bigger multi-page graphic narrative.

Weeks 9-14: Final completion with a mid-level presentation in week 11.

A mid-level draft presentation will be shared in the studio to display the work in progress after 2 weeks then followed by the final 4 weeks or the end of the semester, ready for display, presentation and production. Studio presence in these weeks will be a must.

Output Participation:

Though the output will be individual, the process of production will be based on field research, short studio collaborations and conversations and work-in-progress presentations at regular intervals as discussed above.

Course Deliverables: Every student will be expected to develop, produce multiple research-based short visual stories and graphic narratives/ comics.

description:
Modern Megacities in History and Theory [HIS-3525/ SOA-3091] [HIS-3525/ SOA-3091-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Churiwala Garg [gaurav.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The world’s largest cities evoke extreme reactions. People either hate them or love them, but they cannot ignore them. Fascinating, bewildering, and thought-provoking, megacities can teach us a lot of about our past, present, and the future. According to the United Nations, there were 33 megacities in 2018— cities with populations exceeding 10 million. What global, regional, national and local forces have combined over time— through history—to produce modern megacities? What explains their resilience, growth, diversity, and dynamism? How have megacities and its people coped with this unprecedented concentration of people and capital? What does it mean to live in such cities? Through this course, students will gain a strong footing into the world of historical, social scientific and humanistic scholarship on modern cities and urbanization. Furthermore, students will learn about the complicated dynamics between capitalism, modernity and cities; and will be encouraged to think about the relationship between history, the social sciences and the humanities.

Learning Outcomes

This is an interdisciplinary course that will introduce students to some of the most important readings and themes in the field of global urban studies and urban history. Students will read and think about the relationship between history on one hand, and sociologically and anthropologically informed qualitative scholarship on urban studies on the other. Students will be motivated to challenge and go beyond the old-fashioned but common-sensical division between idiographic and nomothetic approaches to scholarship.

Response Paper 20 per cent of total grade: Students (including those auditing) are to write a 2- page response to the assigned reading and submit by 3PM on the day of the class. Each student must submit at least 8 response papers through the semester. The best 5 papers will be entered into the final grade.

Please note: you will not ordinarily receive feedback on your response unless there are some glaring issues that you need to fix. Late submission will not be accepted. Annotated Bibliography— 20 per cent: Choose a city you will focus on by Sept 30. You will be required to enter your choice in a google sheet that your TPA will provide. You will then prepare an annotated bibliography on the city you are studying. An annotated bibliography consists of a list of readings—properly cited (Chicago Style)—and with a short, paragraph-long abstract. In your case, the bibliography will mainly consist of secondary scholarship on the city you are focusing on. Popular literary sources, newspaper reports, and other audio-visual sources such as movies will be welcome. I expect every annotated bibliography to have at least 10 and not more than 15 entries. You must cover at least 5 themes that we will discuss from the month from mid term onwards.

Monks, Monastery, Modernity [SOA-2213] [SOA-2213-1]

Faculty Name
Swargajyoti Gohain [swargajyoti.gohain@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a course on the anthropology of Buddhism. It begins by exploring some basic questions such as - Is Buddhism one monolithic religion or several plural traditions? What are the main doctrines and institutions of Buddhism? How do the lived practices and institutions in contemporary Buddhist societies adhere to or depart from doctrine?

The course materials investigate what an anthropological approach can tell us about the relation between Buddhist ideas and practices in the contemporary context across different national cultures in Asia. Is Buddhism non-violent? Then how do we interpret the role of monks in violent identity politics and aggressive nationalisms? Was the Buddha a vegetarian?  If not, how does vegetarianism enter into Buddhist environmentalist discourse? Do Buddhist ethics prescribe egalitarianism and inclusion? Then how do gender inequalities persist in Buddhist institutions and practices? Are monasteries spaces for meditation and prayers? Then how are they co-opted into electoral battles? Is Buddhism not about renunciation? Then what do we make of the relations between Buddhism and business?

This course will provide a critical understanding of contemporary Buddhism. Its larger goal is to understand the intersections of religion, politics, and society.

courseTitle: Indian State in a Comparative Perspective
description:
Indian State in a Comparative Perspective [POL-2086] [POL-2086-1]

Faculty Name
Anustubh Agnihotri [anustubh.agnihotri@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Indian state has often been described as a paradox – a state that is both weak and strong due to its ability to effectively carry out some functions while failing to deliver on other crucial aspects. As India celebrates the 75th year of its independence, what are the successes and failures of the Indian state? Why do the successes and failures seem paradoxical when juxtaposed next to each other? Have rapid technological advancements fundamentally altered how the Indian state works? What are possible ways in which the state functioning can be strengthened? The course will rely on a comparative perspective to examine these questions. Throughout the semester, we will explore various dimensions of the Indian state while also comparing India’s performance with other countries such as USA, China, Brazil, and Nigeria. 

The course is broadly divided into two parts – the first part (first five weeks) will introduce students to the major theoretical frameworks used to understand the functioning of the state. We will begin by looking at a range of dominant theoretical paradigms like the principal-agent framework and the state-society framework to understand how politicians or social groups influence the functioning of the state apparatus. The second part will delve into empirical papers and exploration of quantitative metrics on state performance. The theoretical frameworks discussed in the first part will keep reappearing as the course shifts to specific case studies, empirical papers, and analysis of publicly available datasets.   

In the second part of the course, students will read more empirically oriented papers that explore different facets of the workings of the state. The students will also look at national, cross- national, and sub-national datasets 1  to test out the theories. Each week will touch upon a specific area of state functioning like regulating urbanization, providing basic education, delivery of welfare services, etc. The course will involve multiple group projects as well as an individually written final research paper.

Power Elites [POL-3086] [POL-3086-1]

Faculty Name
Rahul Verma [rahul.verma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

No one ever seizes power with the intention of relinquishing it.  Is all politics then just a struggle for power? Should we think of power as "means" or an "end"? This course aims to bring together classic and contemporary work on power elites (political, economic and other such spheres) to understand their role in shaping Indian Democracy as we see it today. Power elites in short are an intricate node of influencers that shapes decision-making in any society at any given point of time. As Pareto reminded us a long time ago that while the nodes of influence may remain the same, individuals who occupy these positions change (ala. circulation of elites). We will make an attempt to understand how power is created, shared, transferred and disrupted. The course covers a range of important topics within the study of elites. First, we will review key theoretical contributions concerning power elites. We will focus on political ambition, examine why people aspire for political office, recruitment process and others. Second, we will also learn about other key sectors such as economic/ business elites, social/ cultural elites, among others to get an overview of the processes that determine the composition of decision-making circles. Third, with the available evidence (and case studies), we hope to develop an understanding of the forces shaping elite behavior and how that in turn is shaping Indian democracy.

Pre-requisites: Introduction to Indian Politics (1004) OR a similar course in Sociology and Anthropology.

courseTitle: Introduction to the Study of China
description:
Introduction to the Study of China [CHI-2001/ HIS-2804/ IR-2038] [CHI-2001/ HIS-2804/ IR-2038-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is China? Who counts as Chinese? What is China’s place in the modern world? Can China only be understood on Chinese terms? These questions have been continuously debated both inside and outside China, with more and more urgency. We will read works by historians, anthropologists, political scientists, sociologists, economists, and other “experts” and commentators to explore how these questions have been answered, who has answered them, and who is allowed to ask them. On the one hand, these questions can be seen as partially representative of China’s social, economic, cultural and intellectual transformation from an empire to a nation-state. On the other hand, and just as importantly, these questions can be seen as partially representative of the global transformations that intersected with and helped shape the direction of China’s changes, just as China firmly integrated itself into global systems and its dominant logics of knowledge production and social formations.

This class will take a historiographical and conceptual approach to the study of these questions. Structured around the discussion of three major themes, namely, history, culture, and philosophy, we will examine what the study of China has meant for different kinds of audiences, and how those perspectives have evolved across time and disciplines. Therefore, we will also pay special attention to how “China” has been explained to academic and popular audiences by non-Chinese commentators. As a deeply heterogenous cultural formation that has transformed and been transformed by other cultures and systems, we will consider what is distinctive, or not, about the study of “China” in our time and our region.

Learning Outcomes

Think critically about the concept of ‘China’ in long-term historical perspective.

Be able to identify multiple alternative sources through which to learn about China, and analyse their strengths and weaknesses.

Identify common tropes in written and visual primary source material related to China.

Analyse the arguments and sources used by scholars in different disciplines writing about China.

courseTitle: Militants or Freedom Fighters? Armed Conflicts in India
description:
Militants or Freedom Fighters? Armed Conflicts in India [POL-2091] [POL-2091-1]

Faculty Name
Kaustav Dhar Chakrabarti [kaustav.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“One person’s freedom fighter is another person’s terrorist” is a common expression that sums up the complexity of armed conflicts around the world. How should we understand the state’s claims to legitimacy versus some of our most cherished beliefs in civil rights and the right to self-determination? This course will approach the question through the lens of theories in political science while being grounded in the empirical realities of armed conflicts across India. The course does not take a normative position on these conflicts – we will not assume that armed groups are ‘unlawful’, neither will we valorise them. We will treat armed conflicts as a political phenomenon of interest, and I invite you to use the course to sharpen and test your prior views.

The course will cover five major themes on armed conflicts. We will begin with establishing a solid conceptual foundation – What are armed conflicts? How are they different from other forms of organized violence? What are armed groups? Next, we will examine the causes of armed conflicts. Are conflicts rooted in political and economic grievances? Or should we blame self-interested leaders?

In the second module, we will study how combat, or war-fighting differs between civil wars and conventional interstate war. We will explore how armed groups organize for war (the lessons of Mao, Irish Republican Army) and how India responds and read counterinsurgency doctrine and examine the effect of ‘hearts and minds’ development programs. The third module covers arguably the core of guerrilla warfare – armed groups’ relations with the community. We will examine how armed groups mobilize support, the depth of their connections with the community and their treatment of civilians, and the methods that they adopt to solicit the community’s support. We will also cover the terrain of pre-existing social institutions and the community’s experience with the incumbent state and examine how it affects its decision to support (or withhold support) to armed groups. 

The fourth modules returns to aspects of armed groups where we will study how commitment to ideology, and robust centralized organization to ensure discipline among cadre, and splintering into factions,  affects the behaviour of armed groups.

The final module covers the role of external factors – foreign bases in inaccessible forests of Myanmar, support from China and Pakistan, the role of diaspora, and ask if the presence of ‘foreign fighters’ should change our understanding. The course culminates with the important theme of conflict resolution; why did military methods succeed in Punjab but not in Kashmir? Why did negotiations succeed in Mizoram but have failed to resolve the dispute in Nagaland? 

Learning Outcomes

The goals of the course are three-fold. By the end of the course, students should have an overview of some of the major debates in the political science of civil war, especially those that are pertinent to India. In addition, the course will familiarise students with major civil wars (or ‘insurgencies’) in India through detailed case studies. Finally, the course will reinforce the department’s continuous training in analytical thinking. It will bolster students’ ability to distinguish between different theoretical explanations, evaluate the merit of competing arguments made in the literature, and communicate their arguments clearly in written form.  

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Please refer to readings from the previous iteration of the course. 

Class 1: Introductions, Greetings, Review of Syllabus. 

Reading and Writing Resources (optional) 

Humphreys, Macartan. Excerpts from Comparative Politics Field Seminar I, Columbia University, 2013

Farrell, Henry. Good Writing in Political Science: An Undergraduate Student’s Short Illustrated Primer, 2010

Edwards, Paul. How to Read a Book, v5.0. School of Information, University of Michigan

MODULE 1: Concepts, Definitions and Causes

What are civil wars, or armed conflicts? How are they different from other forms of organized violence? What are armed groups? What are the causes of armed conflict? Are conflicts rooted in political and economic grievances? Or should we blame self-interested leaders? 

Class 2: What are Civil Wars? 

How does political science define civil wars? If I show you an example, will you be able to tell if it is a civil war or another form of organized violence? What are the major themes in the scholarship of civil wars? Can you identify gaps?  

Kalyvas, Stathis N. 2006. The Logic of Violence in Civil War. Cambridge; New York: Cambridge University Press. (pages 16-31)

Galula, David. 2006. Counterinsurgency Warfare: Theory and Practice. Westport, CT: Praeger Security International. (pages 1-10)

Staniland, Paul. 2012. “States, Insurgents, and Wartime Political Orders.” Perspectives on Politics 10 (02): (pages 244-246, start reading from ‘Concepts and Outcomes..”) 

Tarrow, Sidney. 2007. “Inside Insurgencies: Politics and Violence in an Age of Civil War.” Perspectives on Politics 5 (03): (pages 587-600, read till end of section I). 

Class 3: What Causes Civil Wars to Take Place? 

What are the causes of civil wars? Can you identify explanations that you can confidently dismiss, or explanations that appear particularly relevant to India? 

Wimmer, Andreas. 2013. Waves of War: Nationalism, State Formation, and Ethnic Exclusion in the Modern World. Cambridge England ; New York: Cambridge University Press. Read Chapter 5 - Ethnic Politics and Armed Conflict pp 143-173

Class 4: Case Study of the Kashmir Conflict 

Ganguly, Sumit. “Explaining the Kashmir Insurgency: Political Mobilization and Institutional Decay,” International Security, Vol. 21, No. 2 (Autumn, 1996), pp. 76-107

Varshney, Ashutosh. 1991. “India, Pakistan, and Kashmir: Antinomies of Nationalism.” Asian Survey 31 (11): 997–1019.

Optional Reading 

Staniland, Paul. 2013. “Kashmir since 2003: Counterinsurgency and the Paradox of ‘Normalcy.’” Asian Survey 53 (5): 931–57.

Class 5: Case Study of Punjab Conflict 

What led one of the more prosperous and well-connected regions in the country to experience civil war, a phenomenon associated with poverty and poor connectivity?

 We will read sections from Mark Tully and Satish Jabob’s classic Amritsar, and Mallika Kaur’s soon to be classic, Faith, Gender and Activism in the Punjab Conflict. The readings exceed 35 pages, but the prose is beautifully crafted and makes for quick reading. If you like good writing, read the entire chapters; but I have suggested trimmed selections to cram everything around 45 pages. 

1.     Tully, Mark, and Satish Jacob. 1985. Amritsar: Mrs Gandhi’s Last Battle. J. Cape. [Chapter 3: The Grievances of the Sikhs] 16 pages

2.     Kaur, Mallika. 2020. Faith, Gender, and Activism in the Punjab Conflict: The Wheat Fields Still Whisper. 1st ed. 2019 edition. Basingstoke: Palgrave Macmillan. [Chapter 8: Guavas and Gaslighting, read pages 223-228] 6 pages

3.     Kaur, Mallika. 2020. Faith, Gender, and Activism in the Punjab Conflict: The Wheat Fields Still Whisper. 1st ed. 2019 edition. Basingstoke: Palgrave Macmillan. [Chapter 9: Glasnost] 23 pages.

Class 6: Case Study of the Naxal Conflict 

Mukherjee, Shivaji. 2021. Colonial Institutions and Civil War: Indirect Rule and Maoist Insurgency in India. Cambridge; New York, NY: Cambridge University Press. [Read Chapter 1: Colonial Institutions and Civil War] 

Optional

Sundar, Nandini. 2008. Subalterns and Sovereigns: An Anthropological History of Bastar. 2nd edition. New Delhi: OUP India. [Introduction]

Kennedy, Jonathan. 2014. “Gangsters or Gandhians? The Political Sociology of the Maoist Insurgency in India.” India Review 13 (3): 212–34. 

MODULE 2: Civil War and and Repertoires of State Response 

How is war-fighting or combat in civil wars different from conventional interstate wars? What makes civil wars particularly violent toward civilians? Overview of how states respond through counterinsurgency and ‘hearts and minds’ state-building activities. Examination of whether violence generates negative consequences. 

Class 7: ‘The Logic of Violence’

 Two big questions - What drives the actions of states and armed groups during civil wars? Why are civil wars so violent toward civilians? We read the seminal Logic of Violence in Civil Wars by Kalyvas. The book's theory itself is divided into four chapters. I have curated sections from different works of Kalyvas to provide a full account in around 40 pages. 

Kalyvas, Stathis N. 2006. The Logic of Violence in Civil War. Cambridge University Press. May 2006. (pages pages 89-106, 118-132) 

Kalyvas, Stathis N. 2008. “Promises and Pitfalls of an Emerging Research Program: The Microdynamics of Civil War.” In Order, Conflict, and Violence, edited by Ian Shapiro, Stathis N. Kalyvas, and Tarek Masoud, 397–421. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Pages 405-414 

Lynn, John A. 2005. “Patterns of Insurgency and Counterinsurgency.” MILITARY REVIEW, 6. (pages 22-25, read the section ‘Basic Model of Insurgency/ Counterinsurgency’)

Kilcullen, David J. 2005. “Countering Global Insurgency.” Journal of Strategic Studies 28 (4): 597–617.  (read the section ‘Competing Paradigms – Terrorism and Insurgency’, pages 604-606) 

Please do the readings in the order that I suggest below. 

1. Start with Kalyvas 2012 (pages 660-661, section "The Control Collaboration Model"). This is a one page summary of the argument. 

2. Read Kalyvas 2006 (pages 89-106, section 4.2 to 4.4). This identifies the problem of separating armed groups from ordinary civilians and explains how the community's compliance is generated.  

3. Read Kalyvas 2008 (pages 405-414, begin reading from the sub-title "Omitted Variable Bias"). This is a longer summary of the theory of selective violence. It will familiarise you with the argument that the threat of violence produces community's collaboration.  

4. Read Kalyvas 2006; (pages 118-132, section 5.3 and 5.4). This adds more detail to the previous reading. 

Put together, the four readings will give you a sufficient picture of Kalyvas's argument that is otherwise spread over 100 pages in the book. Don't think about organizing the readings or think about how they speak to each other. Instead, think about the four readings as different accounts of the same argument. 

In addition, supplement Kalyvas with two perspectives from military practitioners. If you are really pressed for time, you can skip these, but I urge you to read them, since it'll enhance your understanding of how guerrilla wars are fought. 

Lynn 2005 (pages 22-25, section "Basic Model of Insurgency/Counterinsurgency"). Ask yourself - is Kalyvas saying the same thing with more bells and whistles?

Kilcullen 2005. (pages 604-606, section "competing paradigms - Terrorism and Insurgency). 

Class 8: Counterinsurgency Doctrine 

Canon of Western (and Indian)- Counterinsurgency Doctrine. We will compare Kalyvas’s ‘logic of violence’ with case studies of how India and the United States understand the nature of civil war and the way to respond to the threat. Two declassified doctrines of the US and Indian military provide an opportunity to carry out this comparison. We will read the selections of the doctrine with their academic criticisms.

US Army/Marine Corps. 2007. Counterinsurgency: FM 3-24. Boulder, Colo: Paladin Press. (see selections below)

Isaac, Jeffrey et. al. 2008. “The New U.S. Army/Marine Corps Counterinsurgency Field Manual as Political Science and Political Praxis.” Perspectives on Politics 6 (02). 

Army Training Command (ARTRAC). 2006. Doctrine for Sub Conventional Operations, Shimla: ARTRAC 

Ahmed, Ali. Revision of the DSCO: Human Rights to the Fore. IDSA Policy Brief. 

Read selections in the following order.  Just to be sure, sections that I have crossed out in the uploaded documents are not to be read.  

 First, read US Army/Marine Corps Counterinsurgency Field Manual (pages 1-1; 1-5 to 1-8) for state’s understanding of civil wars, and pages 1-19 to 1-25; 1-26 to 1-27; 1-28 to 1-29 for state’s understanding of counterinsurgency. 

Second, read reviews of the US doctrine by Stephen Biddle and Stathis Kalyvas in Isaac, Jeffrey et. al. 2008 (pages 347-353). 

Third, read the Indian Army’s Doctrine of Sub-Conventional Operations (pages 8-13, 16-23, and 38-39). 

Fourth, read a review by military officer turned scholar Ali Ahmed (pages 3-6, start from ‘doctrinal dissonance’) where he offers a human rights based review of the doctrine. 

Class 9: Does Violence Incur Negative Consequences?   

Counterinsurgency ‘Hearts and Minds’: Beyond Violence 

Kalyvas tells us that coercion prevails over persuasion, as a result of the strategic nature of the contest between a state and an armed group. On the other hand, COIN doctrines espouse restraint and call for winning ‘hearts and minds’. We extend our understanding of the motivation of armed actors and the consequences of coercion. 

Lyall, Jason, Graeme Blair, and Koseuke Imai. 2013. “Explaining Support for Combatants during Wartime: A Survey Experiment in Afghanistan.” American Political Science Review 107 (04): 679–705.

Sambanis, N., J. Schulhofer-Wohl, and M. Shayo. 2012. “Parochialism as a Central Challenge in Counterinsurgency.” Science 336 (6083): 805–8.

Class 10: Role of Electoral Politics and Parties  

Chandra, Kanchan, and Omar García-Ponce. 2019. “Why Ethnic Subaltern-Led Parties Crowd Out Armed Organizations: Explaining Maoist Violence in India.” World Politics 71(2): 367–416.

Optional Readings 

Kohli, Atul. 1997. “Can Democracies Accommodate Ethnic Nationalism? Rise and Decline of Self-Determination Movements in India.” The Journal of Asian Studies 56 (2): 325.

Lacina, Bethany. 2009. “The Problem of Political Stability in Northeast India: Local Ethnic Autocracy and the Rule of Law.” Asian Survey 49 (6): 998–1020. 

Class 11: What is the Role of Development in Civil Wars? 

 Dasgupta, Aditya, Kishore Gawande, and Devesh Kapur. 2017. “(When) Do AntiPoverty Programs Reduce Violence? India’s Rural Employment Guarantee and Maoist Conflict.” International Organization 71 (3): 605–632

 

MODULE 3: GUERRILLA WAR 

Revolutionary ideologues call for guerrilla war as people’s war. How do they generate support from the community? Do all communities respond alike to armed groups’ call for support? Who supports armed groups? Who joins armed groups? What makes some communities more capable of extending support than others? 

 

Class 12: How do Armed Groups Fight: Canons of Guerrilla Warfare 

What do some of the most iconic thinkers of guerrilla war (or ‘revolutionary war’) think about civil wars? How do they distinguish irregular war from conventional war, and how do they envision defeating a superior adversary? 

 

Zedong, Mao. 1937. On Guerrilla Warfare. University of Illinois Press. (pages 41-57,102-114) 

General Headquarters Irish Republican Army. 1956. Handbook for Volunteers of the Irish Republican Army (chapters 2,3,4,6. They add to 7 pages)

Guevara Ernesto. 1961. Guerrilla Warfare (pages 7-14) 

 

Class 13: Support Through the Strategy of Persuasion   

Mao, Che, and the IRA call for armed groups to generate support from the community. Is this strategy always superior from the perspective of the goal of meeting the larger goal of the movement? What are the pros and cons of the strategy of persuasion? When is this strategy likely to be fruitful? 

Begin with Stewart and Liou who outline the relative strengths of both coercion and persuasion. Then, read Mampilly, and focus on ‘Gramscian balance’, skimming the rest. Finish with Weinstein.   

Stewart, Megan A., and Yu-Ming Liou. 2016. “Do Good Borders Make Good Rebels? Territorial Control and Civilian Casualties.” The Journal of Politics 79 (1): 284–301. [read pages 285-286, look at markings in the uploaded document] 

Mampilly, Zachariah Cherian. 2012. Rebel Rulers: Insurgent Governance and Civilian Life During War. Cornell University Press [pages 50-58]

Weinstein, Jeremy M. 2006. Inside Rebellion: The Politics of Insurgent Violence. Cambridge University Press. [Chapter 5: Governance] [skim]

Nguyen Van Thieu. 1982. Our Strategy for Guerrilla War. In  Chaliand Gérard  (ed) Guerrilla Strategies: An Historical Anthology from the Long March to Afghanistan

 

Optional Readings

Wood, Elisabeth Jean. 2003. “Insurgent Collective Action and Civil War in El Salvador.” Cambridge Core. Cambridge University Press. August 2003. [Chapter 4]

Petersen, Roger Dale. 2001. Resistance and Rebellion: Lessons from Eastern Europe. Cambridge; New York: Cambridge University Press. [Chapters 1 and 2]

 

Class 14:  : Mobilisation - Who Joins Armed Groups? Why?  

Key Questions 

Who Fights? What are the correlates of recruitment into armed groups? 

What are the reasons or motivations that prompt individuals to join armed groups? 

What are the processes through which individuals join armed groups? 

Are individuals who join armed groups different from those who support them from outside? 

Readings 

Humphreys, Macartan, and Jeremy M. Weinstein. 2008. “Who Fights? The Determinants of Participation in Civil War.” American Journal of Political Science 52(2): 436–55. Read for substance, skim the technical sections on statistics. 

Parkinson, Sarah Elizabeth. 2013. “Organizing Rebellion: Rethinking High-Risk Mobilization and Social Networks in War.” American Political Science Review 107(3): 418–32.

Tezcür, Güneş Murat. 2016. “Ordinary People, Extraordinary Risks: Participation in an Ethnic Rebellion.” American Political Science Review 110(02): 247–64. Read abstract and introduction to get the gist of the argument. 

 

Further readings for future research 

Petersen, Roger Dale. 2001. Resistance and Rebellion: Lessons from Eastern Europe.

Cambridge: Cambridge University Press

Gates,  Scott.  2002.  “Recruitment  and  Allegiance:  The  Microfoundations  of  Rebellion.”

Journal  of  Conflict  Resolution  46  (1):  111–130.

Eck, Kristine. 2014. “Coercion in Rebel Recruitment.” Security Studies 23: 364-398. 

Eck, Kristine. 2018. “Recruitment and Violence in Nepal’s Civil War: Microstudies under the Microscope.” Asian Survey 58(2): 261-280.

 

Class 15: Community Collective Action – Dense Social Ties and Armed Group-Community Ties 

Key Questions 

What is/are the difference(s) between individual level unit of analysis and community level unit of analysis?

What is the difference between bonding ties and bridging ties? 

What kind of social networks come to the aid of armed groups? 

What are the mechanisms through which social networks aid armed groups? 

Reading 

Sarbahi, Anoop. 2021. “The Structure of Religion, Ethnicity, and Insurgent Mobilization: Evidence from India.” World Politics 73 (1): 82–127. 

Further readings for future research

Staniland, Paul. 2012. “Organizing Insurgency: Networks, Resources, and Rebellion in South Asia.” International Security 37 (1): 142–77.  

Rubin, Michael A. 2020. “Rebel Territorial Control and Civilian Collective Action in Civil War: Evidence from the Communist Insurgency in the Philippines.” Journal of Conflict Resolution 64(2–3): 459–89.

 

MODULE 4: ARMED GROUPS REDUX

Mao and Guevera lay out a blueprint of revolutionary war and paint the revolutionary guerrilla as a social reformer who patiently wins over the community to fight against the stronger state. Do revolutionary practitioners remain true to theory? In this module, we examine some factors that influence the behaviour of armed groups, especially their treatment of community members - access to external sources of funding, splintering, and collaboration with the state.

 

Class 16: External Support and Consequences on Behaviour Toward Community Members 

Toft, Monica Duffy, and Yuri M. Zhukov. 2015. “Islamists and Nationalists: Rebel Motivation and Counterinsurgency in Russia’s North Caucasus.” American Political Science Review 109 (2): 222–38. 

Salehyan, Idean, David Siroky, and Reed M. Wood. 2014. “External Rebel Sponsorship and Civilian Abuse: A Principal-Agent Analysis of Wartime Atrocities.” International Organization 68 (3): 633–61.

 

Class 17: Armed Group Fragmentation and Fratricide 

Two articles that explain why armed groups splinter into rival factions and the dynamics of factional violence. In the following class, we will take up the related topic of how some armed groups switch sides and ally with the state.  

 

1. McLauchlin, Theodore, and Wendy Pearlman. 2012. “Out-Group Conflict, In-Group Unity? Exploring the Effect of Repression on Intramovement Cooperation.” The Journal of Conflict Resolution 56 (1): 41–66.

2. Pischedda, Costantino. 2018. “Wars within Wars: Why Windows of Opportunity and Vulnerability Cause Inter-Rebel Fighting in Internal Conflicts.” International Security 43 (1): 138–76.

 

Class 18: Fragmentation and Armed group-State Collaboration

We extend the discussion of conflict among armed groups to a related question - why do armed groups ‘flip’ and collaborate with the state.  

 

1. Staniland, Paul. 2012. “Between a Rock and a Hard Place: Insurgent Fratricide, Ethnic Defection, and the Rise of Pro-State Paramilitaries.” Journal of Conflict Resolution 56 (1): 16–40.

2. Staniland, Paul. 2017. “Armed Politics and the Study of Intrastate Conflict.” Journal of Peace Research 54 (4): 459–67. 

 

MODULE 5: CASE STUDIES, GENDER. CONFLICT TERMINATION

 

Class 19: Nagaland 

The story of Nagaland and Mizoram have similar beginnings, but take different trajectories at the turn of Partition. Read for – state violence, guerrilla war, fratricidal violence, and peace-making both with India and among armed factions. 

Wouters, Jelle J. P. 2018. In the Shadows of Naga Insurgency: Tribes, State, and Violence in  India’s Northeast. Oxford University Press. (Chapter 4)

Chakrabarti, Kaustav. 2021. Underground Governance: Rules-Based Order by Armed Groups in Northeast India [dissertation, Brown University]. (Chapter 4, selections)

Sundar, Nandini. 2011. “Interning Insurgent Populations: The Buried Histories of Indian Democracy,” no. 6: 11. [repeat reading, revise your notes from the Mizoram reading]

The readings are more voluminous than I could have liked, but many sections can be skimmed, and the time that it takes to read will be less than the number of pages would otherwise suggest. Jelle Wouters is one of my favourite writers and a role model for beautiful prose. He shows two faces of the state in Nagaland - one that is coercive and the other that is developmental. Skim his engagement with anthropology theory and read for content that shows the state’s two dimensions. Follow it with a chapter from my dissertation (pages 6-34, begin from ‘Summary of Evidence’ and read till end of Section 3). The chapter shows how factional conflict is different from state-armed group conflict. Case studies of Dimapur and Kohima also show both ‘tribalism’ at play and armed group-community ties. Skim the sections on governance and focus on factional conflict and armed group-community ties. Revise your notes for the Sundar article that you have read for Mizoram. 

 

Class 20: Mizoram 

Mizoram is a remarkable case study of both war and peace, which makes its relative absence in scholarly debates all the more perplexing.

Pachuau, Joy L. K., and Willem van Schendel. 2015. The Camera as Witness. Cambridge University Press.

Sundar, Nandini. 2011. “Interning Insurgent Populations: The Buried Histories of Indian Democracy,” no. 6: 11.

Jafa, Vijendra Singh. 2001. “Counterinsurgency Warfare The Use & Abuse of Military Force.” South Asia Terrorism Portal.

Lalrawnliana. 2014. Freedom Struggle in Mizoram. Aizawl: self-published.

Start with Chapter 17 of Pachuau and van Schendel. Prof Pachuau who teaches at JNU and is herself from Mizoram presents a history of Mizo society through photographs. This chapter will ‘show’ details of civil war. Follow it by reading Nandini Sundar’s oral history of civil war in both Mizoram and Nagaland, where she focuses on the strategy of grouping, or forced displacement of village communities into internment camps.

Two accompanying articles provide primary source evidence. Read Jafa’s (another IAS officer who continues to be hugely admired, as I found out, in Mizoram) recollection of a candid conversation with a military officer who questioned the morality of his actions (pages 10-12, start with the highlighted part). Do not miss selections from a memoir of Lalrawnliana, a former commander of the Mizo Army that captures vivid details of guerrilla warfare and the role of the community.   

Class 21: Assam 

Baruah, Sanjib. 2005. Durable Disorder: Understanding the Politics of Northeast India. New Delhi; New York: OUP India. Chapter 7: The Indian State and ULFA

Baruah, Sanjib. 2005. Durable Disorder: Understanding the Politics of Northeast India. New Delhi; New York: OUP India. Chapter 8: Twenty-Five Years Later: A Diminished Democracy 

Mahanta, Nani Gopal. 2013. Confronting the State: ULFA’s Quest for Sovereignty. New Delhi: Sage Publications. Chapter 5, read pages 144-145

 

Class 22: Civil War and Gender 

Trigger Warning: Anubha Bhonsle’s case study has details of sexual violence against  Manorama, a young women from Manipur whose death prompted Irom Sharmila to a 16-year long hunger strike to demand the repel of the Armed Forces Special Powers Act. If you feel that reading this might cause you discomfort, please skip the first few pages and begin from page 112 - ‘At the Nupi Samaj, a prominent Meira Paibi group….’ 

 

Theory 

Bakken, Ingrid Vik, and Halvard Buhaug. 2021. “Civil War and Female Empowerment.” Journal of Conflict Resolution 65(5): 982–1009. [Read pages 982-990 and 1000-1003] 

 

Case Studies 

Meitei community: Bhonsle, Anubha. 2016. Mother, Where’s My Country?: Looking for Light in the Darkness of Manipur. Latest Edition. New Delhi, India: Speaking Tiger Publishing Private Limited. [Read Chapter 8 ‘Indian Army, Rape Us!’, pages 108-121] 

Naga Community: Manchanda, Rita. 2005. Naga Women Making a Difference: Peace Building in Northeastern India. Women Waging Peace Policy Commission. [Read Part Two: Women’s Contributions to the Peace Process. Pages 12-27] 

Kuki/Zomi Community: Sharma, G Amarjit. 2018. “Politics of the Informal: Women’s Associational Life and Public Space in the Hills of Manipur.” Economic and Political Weekly 53(8): 48–55.

 

Class 23: Kashmir 

Hasnain, Syed Ata. 2012. Kashmir: Analysing “Heart is My Weapon” Doctrine. South Asian Idea 

"Everyone Lives in Fear" Patterns of Impunity in Jammu and Kashmir. 2006.  Human Rights Watch. Vol 18, No 11(C). See selections below 

 

The Human Rights Watch report is extensive and voluminous. To keep the reading manageable, read the summary and key recommendations (pages 1-11). Then move to Section V and Section VI. The two sections provide a glimpse into the nature of violence carried out by state and armed groups. We will try to compare them. 

 In Section V, read the introduction to the section, and introduction to sub-parts A, B, C and D. In each sub-part, read a couple of examples. Do the same for Section VI.  

 

Class 24: Civil War Resolution/Termination 

How do conflicts end? What explains the successful transition to peace in Mizoram, a two-decade long ceasefire without conflict resolution in Nagaland, and continued hostility in Manipur?  

Walter, Barbara F. 1997. “The Critical Barrier to Civil War Settlement.” International

Organization 51 (3):

Jafa, V.S. “Mizoram Contours of Non-Military Intervention.” Faultlines. Available online  

 https://www.satp.org/satporgtp/publication/faultlines/volume4/Fault4-JafaF1.htm.

Mahadevan, Prem. 2008. “A Model for 21st Century Counter-Terrorism? -.”Faultlines  Vol 19. Available online - 

https://www.satp.org/satporgtp/publication/faultlines/volume19/article1.htm.

 Begin by reading Walter’s famous 1997 article about commitment problem as a major barrier toward conflict resolution. Follow it with contrasting case studies of military approaches to conflict termination in Punjab (Mahadevan, read only the Conclusion) and political negotiations in Mizoram (Jafa, read the last section ‘Towards Peace and Settlement’). Note that both case studies are drawn from South Asia Terrorism Portal, which has a reputation of celebrating militaristic strategies.

No readings!!

Overview

This course is designed to provide an introduction to psychotherapy skills. Students will be able to understand elements of ethical and effective counseling practice. They will be able to identify and use a variety of helping Skills at a beginner level with an appreciation of personal and sociocultural factors. The course also aims to enhance student understanding of self as a tool and increase self-awareness and self-reflective abilities. Students will practice helping skills with each other every week. Attendance is mandatory and contributes to the course grade. Note that the course will involve discussing and working with emotionally charged content. Students should also be prepared to reflect on, and talk about (not mandated) some personal/emotional issues in class.

Learning Outcomes

At the completion of this course, students will be able to…

  • Identify helping skills, analyze their function, and evaluate their usefulness
  • Demonstrate a working knowledge of the Hill three-stage model of helping.
  • Use helping skills at a beginner level
  • Articulate ways their & others’ use of helping skills are influenced by personal and larger sociocultural characteristics
