Statistics for Economics [ECO-1400/ CS-1207] [ECO-1400/ CS-1207-1]

Faculty Name
Parush Arora [parush.arora@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is compulsory for all Economics Majors, PPE as well as Economics Minor. This course introduces students to the probability and statistical methods necessary for the study of economics at the undergraduate level. In particular, the course will cover random variables, probability distribution, joint probability distribution, interval estimation and hypothesis testing.

Learning Outcomes

• The course will introduce students to the statistical method, viz., deducing the characteristics of a population from observing the characteristics of a sample. The main objective of the course is to convey to the students why we need to understand statistics for scientific inference.

• This will introduce students to the concept of random samples, random variables, and their distributions which will be needed to move from the properties of a sample to that of an underlying population.  This will be preceded by a quick recap of probability theory.

• The second half of the course will introduce students to methods of statistical inference, testing the significance of sample characteristics.

• Students will be introduced to basic STATA/R coding which will help them with the Econometrics course in the next semester.

• Students will be given problem sets regularly throughout the semester for problem-solving practice.

• Statistical techniques are the building blocks that you need for econometrics, the course you will do in the Spring 2024 semester if you decide to major in Econ.

• I will hopefully persuade you why statistics is important and how it differs from data science or ML techniques that use big data.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required Course Material

1. Ross, Sheldon M.2004. "Introduction to Probability and Statistics for Engineers and Scientists", Third Edition, Elsevier Press. (Ross, henceforth)

2. Peck, Roxy, Olsen, Chris and Devore, Jay. 2012 "Introduction to Statistics and Data Analysis", Fourth Edition, Brooks/Cole Cengage Learning (POD, hence-forth)

3. We will also refer to Ross, Sheldon.  A First Course in Probability, 8th Edition. (Ross 2, henceforth)

Other material, including online resources, might be introduced during the semester, but those would be optional.

Grading Rubric

Student grades have four components: final exam (50% weightage), first mid-term (20% weightage), second exam (20% weightage), and the total score in all problem sets combined (10% weightage). The syllabus for the first and second mid-term exams will be announced in class and on AMS/Moodle.

The Ashoka grading scheme:

A letter grade = outstanding. Students know the mathematical techniques and have the ability to apply them to novel problems.

B letter grade = good.  Students have expertise in most of the mathematical techniques taught in the course.  They may lack creativity in problem-solving but are well-trained to do well in any mathematical or applied course.

C letter grade = adequate. The student knows enough. If s/he tries to revise the course content, s/he shall do well in any application of the course content.

D letter grade = barely satisfactory.  The student knows little.  S/he requires guidance and then s/he would be able to apply the courses’ concepts.

F letter grade = unsatisfactory. The student knows less than 40% of the course content. S/he has not achieved the minimum standards for this course

Attendance Policy

1. Attendance is NOT mandatory though attending lectures and Discussion Sections are highly recommended. However, keep in mind that you will be responsible for all the material covered in class. I highly encourage you all to ask questions for concepts you do not understand.

2. Please turn off your cell phones or put them on vibrate and be courteous to me and your fellow students in your use of other electronic devices.

3. Graphical calculators are not allowed but scientific calculators are allowed.

4. There is zero tolerance for academic dishonesty during exams. If you are found cheating, you will get an automatic F in the course.

Overview

This course will introduce the students to the contents of the universe and the physical processes that occur in them.  It will describe how, starting from the big bang, the universe expanded to its present size, what forces it experienced, the nature of dark matter and dark energy, how galaxies, stars and planets formed, the origin and properties of compact objects such as neutron stars and black holes and the predicted future course of evolution of the universe.  The prime role of General Theory of Relativity in many of these processes will be highlighted.

description:
Odissi and the art of movement [CPA-0077] [CPA-0077-1]

Faculty Name
Supriya Nayak [supriya.nayak@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course seeks to provide students with tools to explore and develop an understanding of what constitutes dance, movement and expression, from different perspectives. We will approach the subject through a series of personal movement explorations and questions on the one hand, and by developing an understanding of Odissi—a formal, performance-centred dance style—on the other. 

Using resources such as performance videos, photographs and historical essays, we will become familiar with the sources of inspiration for Odissi practitioners in its formative decades in the mid-twentieth century. Together with this, there will be a practical focus on learning a range of stances, movements and rhythms drawn from Odissi. 

Alongside, we will explore our own personal connection (or the lack of it) with dance in social and performative contexts. If moving and dancing feel good and help us connect with the world around us, what are the barriers that come in the way of following this pleasure?

We will aim to cultivate a critical regard of ‘classical’ dance history in India through the case of Odissi, together uncovering what was left out in the creation and propagation of a standardised, 'classical' style of dance, and how the dance's growing popularity has aided and hindered its practitioners.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Classes will be largely practical, with guided exercises and explorations for developing body-mind awareness, and focused learning of basic Odissi movements, stances and rhythms. Resources for the course including a list of video links on social media, photographs and short text excerpts, will be shared on the Google classroom when required for students to access the materials before coming to class. We will watch and discuss the videos, photographs and texts in class together to understand the grammar and choreographic structures of Odissi and work towards developing a project for the CC mela on November 27.

Overview

This course seeks to reflect on care and love both conceptually and experientially. What does it mean to care for and love oneself and others? What allows us to love and care? What prevents us from loving and caring for ourselves and others? What forces—personal, interpersonal, or collective and communal—regulate, prescribe and even prohibit experiences and expressions of love. To paraphrase the narrator of The God of Small Things, this course attempts reflections on the “Love Laws” that determine who can be loved, how and how much.

The texts chosen for our study have been selected from literature, cinema, and television. In their own unique ways, each text deals with such themes through representations of experiences from subject positions that lie outside of “traditional” and “normative” structures within which love and care are usually understood and experienced. The primary objective of the course then is to develop a critical language towards understanding and addressing care and love as the basis for a relationship with oneself and between oneself and others.

description:
The New Geography of the Information Age [CS-2378/ POL-2070/ MS-3511] [CS-2378/ POL-2070/ MS-3511-1]

Faculty Name
Debayan Gupta [debayan.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course focuses on socio-technical problems caused by humanity blindly stumbling its way into the Information Age. Our new world has new rules: intellectual property looks different, cyber-crime looms large, cold cyber-warfare persists at a nation-state level, planet-scale surveillance is commonplace, we're all about to lose our jobs to robots, and the list goes on.

We shall study the rise of fake news and nation-state propaganda, the nature of sensitive information and the importance of privacy, and the deeper structural issues (such as the nature of the internet, the laws of scale, and the direction of technological progress, especially in AI) that underlie many of our problems. We will also spend significant time understanding how these issues affect our political processes (and how personal autonomy and "consent" are affected). Some background in graph theory will be helpful (though not required).

While this course shall be interesting for computer science experts and non-experts alike, we’ll hold extra sessions for non-expert students: you should be willing to get their hands dirty! Students will also be expected to do some background reading on the history of the internet, cyber-crime, etc.

Note that this will be a HARD course (I will be teaching at a graduate level), and you will be dealing with ill-defined real-world problems with missing information.

The syllabus is broken into five "theses":
1. Resources: Humans, Money, and Material (includes data)
2. Control:   Propaganda, Surveillance, Crimes, War
3. Flow:      Structure of the Internet and Sensitive Information
4. Delusion:  Presence is Power. Understanding cultural heritage and identity.
5. Robots:    Is AI going to take over the world?

We will be looking at all of these topics through a technical lens, and it is expected that students will use their own backgrounds and experiences to enrich these conversations. Think about how you might add to the discussion if we discuss how China is using AI in Xinjiang (or the COMPAS system used for bail applications in NY).

Learning Outcomes

You should have a more nuanced, wider, and deeper understanding of the interplay between computing and human society and its many facets, from the economics and supply chains involved, to elections and propaganda, to individual-level behavioral changes.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

List of Readings (you'll be assigned specific chapters, but many end up reading the whole thing; I will provide access to books). I am only listing long readings; there will be numerous shorter articles posted weekly.

Bernays; Propaganda
Shambaugh; China's Propaganda System: Institutions, Processes and Efficacy
Zuboff; The Age of Surveillance Capitalism
Levine; Surveillance Valley
Graeber; Bullshit Jobs
Gray; Ghost Work
Work; US War Doctrine in the Robotic Age
OpenAI Team; GPT-3 Documentation
Johns; Piracy
Shaxson; Treasure Islands

Grading Rubric

50% course notes, 50% final project. Auditors can skip the final project and do only the course notes (this is non-negotiable).

Course notes: This is not just scribing what is said in class: these should be detailed, well-researched, and propely cited notes on specific topics which will be metioned in-class. Must be submitted weekly.

Final project: A pre-submission is required 4 weeks before the course ends, and the final submission is due on the last day of class.

This course looks at the jungle and the wilderness in the Indian subcontinent from antiquity onwards.  In what forms did the jungle enter into ancient Indian imagination? Overview

This course will introduce general techniques of data analysis and of drawing inference from multi-attribute, multi-mesenger data.  Specific examples from Astronomy will be used, but the underlying methods will have applicability in a wide variety of domains.

Syllabus:

Brief overview of different electromagnetic bands and the instruments employed for astronomical data collection.  Ground vs Space based astronomy. Inference from data, role and techniqes of model fitting.  Temporal, spectral and direct/indirect imaging data will be treated in an unified framework.

Types of data - Image data, Spectral data, Temporal data, Interferometry data, Event data.
Principles of reduction of different data types. Calibration requirements.  Background estimation and removal. Error estimates.  Elements of Fourier analysis.

Astronomical data and metadata formats:  The FITS standard.  Viewing, writing and manipulating FITS files.  The AstroPy package.

Hands-on analysis of data including introduction to packages:

Optical: IRAF
Measuring the optical magnitude of a star. Estimating the surface brightness profile of a galaxy. Reduction of a one-dimensional spectrum - wavelength calibration, line identification, continuum subtraction, line profile fitting and radial velocity measurement.

X-ray/Gamma-ray: HEASOFT
Binning of event data to create image, spectrum and light curve.  Response Matrix and Auxiliary Response Files.  Orbital motion of a space-based observatory and charged particle background.
Temporal analysis of Crab pulsar data - barycentric correction, power spectral estimation, epoch folding, phase tracking.  Estimation of spin and spin-down rate.  Transient detection: GRB

Radio interferometry: friendlyVRI, CASA
Creation of an image from visibility data, snapshot vs earth rotation synthesis.  Spectral channels and data cubes.  Local Standard of Rest correction.

Gravitational Waves
Matched filtering through a burst segment

This course is intended to familiarise the students with the analysis of multi-messenger astronomical data at different wavebands, including optical, X-ray, radio and gravitational waves.

Faculty Name

Overview

This course is an undergraduate level introduction to the discipline of International Relations (IR). The course is structured to acquaint the students with both mainstream and critical approaches to the subject, examining how these theories conceptualize ‘the international’ as a field of study.  The course is divided into three sections:the first section of readings review the state of the field and its origins, asking whose voices have dominated IR and whoseinterests and perspectives they speak. The second section provides an overview of the various theoretical frameworks that have come to define the field. The last section of the course concerns the future of the discipline highlighting someof the pertinent debates and questions to be addressed by the discipline. The overall objective of the course is to give students a broad grounding in the wide theoretical terrain of the field and to sensitize students to differences in thenature of knowledge claims (epistemology) and fundamental assumptions about social/international reality (ontology)as well as political and ethical implications of different theoretical approaches in IR.

Grading Rubric

A) Attendance and Class participation (15%)
B) Midterm Assessment: In Class Examination (30%) 
C) Reflections on Theory (15%) 
D) End Semester Essay (40%)

Foreign Policy Analysis [IR-2050] [IR-2050-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Jai Pal Julka [amit.julka@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Introduction

 

As a discipline, IR is initially taught in terms of grand theories – realism, liberalism, constructivism, Marxism – which try to explain in one fell swoop, the entirety of international politics. Foreign policy analysis is granular for it examines how policy-makers decide. As you will learn, actual decision-making is always messier than what grand theories imply. So, from the grand and the ‘macro’, we look on the domestic, state, organizational, and personal levels to understand the multitude of factors that affect a country’s foreign policy. In order to do this, we make use of various conceptual lenses: theories of rational choice, individual/group psychology, emotions, culture/identity, and political economy. In other words, this course will be an exercise in unlearning IR Theory 101.

So, what are the kind of questions that this class will help you think through? Perhaps questions such as ‘How did Nehru’s experience of colonial subjugation shape his ideas of non-alignment?’, Why did the US armed forces support the blockade option during the Cuban Missile Crisis?,  ‘How does the Pakistan Army’s organizational culture affect the country’s attitude towards India?’, ‘Does the shale-lobby affect Canada’s international commitments towards global warming?’, and ‘Does race impact EU’s refugee policy?’

Now the brass tacks – this is a core course and it will have an exam component (see below). In addition, you will also be required to submit one-page (500 words) weekly memos in which you are required to engage with the readings of that week. The tone of these may not be necessarily ‘academic’ – it can be conversational, reflective, or humorous. However, you will be expected to analyze, critique, and go beyond the text. What a memo WILL NOT BE is a summary of the readings.  

Also, an plagiarism (including ChatGPT) will result in an immediate FAIL. No exceptions.

Assessment Methods

The course includes both continuous and cumulative forms of assessment.

For continuous assessment, the students are required to submit six 500-word memos during the course of the entire semester (as per their choice of weeks). The aim of the memo is to make sure students both read and critically analyze the readings

Furthermore, there will be a mid-semester examination in which students will be tested on the fundamentals of foreign policy analysis 

At the end of the semester, students will have to write a 2500 word essay, the prompts for which will be provided beforehand. Students will have to choose one of the prompts for the end-semester essay

Participation in the class and the discussion sessions (run by a Teaching fellow) will also constitute a part of the grade. 

 

Grading Weightage

Memos: 20%

Mid Term Exam: 30%

End Semester Essay: 30%

Participation and Attendance: 20%

Dipankar Bhattacharya [dipankar.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Computational modelling is an essential tool in Astrophysics and Geophysics.  Comprehension of diverse physical effects including fluid and gas flow under gravity, heat and radiation transport, oscillations and seismology, formation of structures in the universe etc is being developed through computations.  This course will introduce the students to some of the basic techniques to perform such computational modelling.    At the heart of the mathematical description of these problems are partial differential equations (PDEs).  Several common methods used to solve PDEs will be discussed, with application examples drawn from Astrophysical and Geophysical settings.   Method of inference from observational data will also be discussed.

The following is an outline of the syllabus:

1. Ordinary and Partial differential equations; Different discretization schemes - Finite difference, Finite Volume and Finite element methods; Euler, Crank-Nicholson and Runge-Kutta integration schemes. Fourier Transforms and Spectral Methods.
2. Applications to the structure and oscillations of stellar and planetary bodies, N-body simulations and formation of structure in the universe, Geophysical heat and material transport.
3. Bayesian inference from observed data. Basic Monte Carlo and MCMC techniques.

Learning Outcomes

1. Learn to formulate physical problems in a computational setting
2. Learn various algorithms for solving problems described by differential equations, their pros and cons and domain of applicability.
3. Experience hands-on the application of numerical techniques to astrophysical and geophysical problems
4. Learn methods to draw statistical inference from data

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites:

Coding ability in any one programming language such as Python, C, C++ or FORTRAN.   Familiarity with differential and integral calculus. Basic knowledge of classical mechanics and thermodynamics.  Basic plotting and visualisation techniques.

2. Finite Volume Methods for Hyperbolic Problems - by Randall J. Leveque, Cambridge University Press
3. Numerical Solutions of Partial Differential Equations - by K.W. Morton and D.F. Mayers, Cambridge University Press
4. Partial Differential Equations for Scientists and Engineers - by Stanley F. Farlow, Dover Publications

6. Data Analysis: A Bayesian Tutorial by D.S. Sivia and J. Skilling, Oxford University Press

This twenty lecture course examines changes and constants in the geopolitics affecting India’s foreign and security policies since independence in 1947. It first considers chronologically the factors that affected Indian policy, its international context, and the role of personalities, structures and strategic culture in the making of that policy as it evolved over seven decades. courseTitle: Populism in Comparative Perspective: Theoretical and Empirical Approaches
description:
Populism in Comparative Perspective: Theoretical and Empirical Approaches [POL-2114] [POL-2114-1]

Faculty Name
Sushmita Nath [sushmita.nath@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We live in populist times. Today’s strongmen, such as Trump, Modi, and Orbán, demonstrate the rising popularity of populist leadership around the world. This has resulted in a significant rise in the number of scholars studying populism in the recent years, and it is now considered as one of the most contentious issues in contemporary political science. Whether it is the rise and popularity of right-wing nationalism in countries such as India, Israel, Italy or Turkey, or the turn to "democratic authoritarianism" in several constitutional democracies in the world today, or the role of social media as decisive in electoral politics in linking the leader to the masses, populism is seen as a central concept to understand all these contemporary challenges. In order to understand the concept and the political practice of populism, we not only need to examine it both in contemporary times and in history, but also the different forms it has assumed in societies as diverse as Hungary, India, the UK, the Philippines, Brazil, Turkey, the United States of America etc. These varied experiences with populism have also resulted in a diversity of approaches to study this phenomenon. This course will introduce students to influential theories of populism as well as empirical experiences of populism in countries such as India, the United States of America, as well as countries in Latin America and Europe. Analysing populism in various countries will help ground theoretical discussions to the empirical realities of populist politics.

The syllabus is divided in two parts: in Part – I we will study the key approaches and theoretical debates on populism; in Part – II we will study specific case-studies of populism by focussing on countries with a long history and/or recent experience of populism. Throughout the semester, students will be familiarized with the key approaches and theoretical debates on populism, as well as its empirical manifestations in various countries, all the while tracing the conceptual changes and challenges to this concept in its relation to democracy, nationalism and media. For this course please be prepared to read approx. 50-100 pages per week.

Design and Analysis of Algorithms [CS-1206] [CS-1206-1]

Faculty Name
Sandeep Sen [sandeep.sen@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will introduce students to the mathematical modeling and solution of computational problems, and teach them how to design and analyze efficient algorithms. The students will:

1. Cover the standard algorithmic paradigms like induction, divide- and-conquer, prune-and-search, greedy, dynamic programming and a toolkit of common algorithms including randomized tech- niques for design, correctness proofs and rigorous analysis of time and space complexity.
2. Explore different ways of thinking about and representing problems coming from diverse domains like sets, graphs, geometry, algebra and number-theory.
3. Develop an understanding of performance metrics like worst-case, average-case and expected-case and how the underlying compu- tational framework is intrinsically tied to the design of efficient algorithms and the notion of optimality.


Detailed coverage: 

Techniques for the design and analysis of efficient algorithms, emphasizing methods useful in practice. Topics include divide- and-conquer; dynamic programming; greedy algorithms; branch and bound; backtracking; amortized analysis; randomized techniques and randomized data structures; graph algorithm including flows and matching. Advanced topics may include computational geometry including dimension-reduction techniques, number-theoretic algorithms, polyno- mial and matrix calculations, external-memory and caching, and some flavor of distributed and parallel computing. Introduction to NP-Completeness, reductions and approximation algorithms.

Learning Outcomes

This course will enable students to think algorithmically and apply imporant algorithms to advanced areas, including but not limited to Computer Science. The students will understand the difference between provable guarantees of resource bounds like time and space complexity by using rigorous mathematical analysis and intuitive heuristics relying on empirical testing that can fail in critical situations. The more mature student would also learn to customize textbook algorithms for specifc applications and computational framework.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: Data Structures, Probability and Statistics. We will not be using a textbook as such, but you may refer to one or the following textbooks for additional reading :

  • Design and Analysis of Algorithms - A contemporary perspective by Sandeep Sen andAmit Kumar, Pub: Cambridge (Indian edition available)

  • Introduction to Algorithms by Cormen, Leiserson and Rivest, Stein, Pub: MIT Press (Indianreprint by Prentice Hall)

  • The Design and Analysis of Computer Algorithms by Aho, Hopcroft and Ullman, Pub- Addison Wesley (Indian reprint available)

  • Algorithms by Dasgupta, Papadimitriou and Vazirani, Pub: Tata McGraw-Hill.

  • Algorithm Design by Kleinberg and Tardos Low Priced Ed. by Pearson.

Overview

So you don’t want to be a lawyer. Or maybe you do. Who knows, and who cares, because either way, a general understanding of key legal concepts – and the ability to think like a lawyer – will add invaluably to your arsenal as you step out into the real world. This knowledge and skillset will make you a distinctly sharper leader in the business world, because legal issues routinely – and increasingly – strike at the heart of business risks and opportunities, and are integral to overall corporate strategy. And so not just lawyers but a wide range of business executives (including C-suite executives) and their advisors routinely work on legal issues alongside lawyers. Legal roles are increasingly business roles, and vice versa. Therefore, the knowledge and skills this course provides will make you a sharper entrepreneur, or a sharper business executive, or a sharper consultant to businesses across sectors. But that’s not all. The benefits extend to countless roles even beyond the business world: you’ll be a sharper problem-solver regardless of field. To this end, the course will explore key concepts across several fundamental areas of law including contracts, torts, constitutional, criminal, administrative, competition, and procedural – each of which is applicable across a wide range of professional fields. The course will explore these concepts in two jurisdictions: India and the U.S. The course will also introduce students to thinking (and related) skills fundamental to not just the legal profession but also to the many professional roles (discussed above) that require frequent engagement with the law or with lawyers. These skills include: contract construction and interpretation; analyzing and applying a case; textual interpretation more broadly; analytical writing; persuasive writing; persuasive verbal argument; and highly analytical thinking with unrelenting precision, agility, and creativity.

Overview

In this course, we seek to offer a global perspective on the evolution of modern warfare and strategy  within  a historical context. We will also follow  its manifestations in international politics today. While delving into different case studies from India, Afghanistan, Vietnam and Ukraine, we will evaluate the possibilities and limitations of different causal explanations of  warfare, and their embeddedness within diverse traditions of strategic thought, including from within Asia, as well as Western Europe. Synthesis of molecules are the very first step towards any specific application, whether it is for medicinal, device or any other purpose. Everything at the bottom is a molecule, which can be synthesized.

As a part of this lab course a training about safe handling of chemical, reaction set-up, using various reagents, working-up and purification of crude product will be practiced through various synthesis experiments. Synthesized compounds need to be characterized by various analytical methods including Infrared spectroscopy, NMR, and Mass spectrometric techniques.

Students will perform some one-step and some multi-step synthesis, learn purification and characterization of those products. The list experiments is given in following:

  • General Instructions: Safety guidelines, collecting information about reagents, preparing lab report, planning a reaction, monitoring the progress of a reaction, planning purification of prepared compound and characterization
  • Cyclohexanol to 1,6-hexanedioic acid (adipic acid) using a ring opening oxidation with nitric acid. Characterization by FT-IR
  • Synthesis of tert-Butyl Chloride (a SN1 Reaction) & its characterization by FT-IR
  • Synthesis of a tetraamido macrocyclic ligand (TAML) and its Fe-complex
  • Synthesis of Fe and Ni-Oxalate complexes and their thermal decomposition study
  • Synthesis of Nylon polymer
  • Synthesis of o- and p-Nitrophenol (Electrophilic Aromatic Substitution)
  • Synthesis of Dibenzalacetone (Aldol Condensation)
  • Friedel-Crafts Acylation
  • Synthesis of Co, Ni and Cu Complexes of 8-hydroxyquinoline
Learning Outcomes

This course will provide a comprehensive understanding about performing organic reactions, which is the first step towards the preparation of any complex molecule. Designing the synthetic route based on available starting materials, monitoring the progress of reaction, purification and then finally characterization are some of the learning outcomes here.

Faculty Name
Priyam Verma [priyam.verma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, we will understand the primitives of a spatial economy and how fundamental forces shape the distribution of economic activities across cities, regions, and countries. We will learn to model location decisions by households and firms and why they gravitate towards large cities, especially in developing countries. We will study the use of GIS software to map infrastructure networks into spatial models. In the presence of congestion, we will understand the effect of trans- portation improvement on spatial reallocation of economic activity. We will delve with measuring agglomeration and amenity spillovers, both of which combined can explain rise and fall of cities. At last, we will learn formulas (sufficient statistics) to compute gains from lowering spatial frictions in a trading economy.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes:

  • Learn how to think about spatial questions in a model-based setup such that it can be quantified for giving guidance to policy makers.
  • Introduced to concepts from spatial, macro, international trade, and labor economics litera- ture for wide applicability and comprehensive analysis of policy questions.
  • Learn to use empirical results as inputs in quantitative models so that our frameworks are a good representation of reality.

  • Jan K. Brueckner (2011) Lectures on Urban Economics, MIT Press.
  • Fujita, M., P. Krugman, and A. Venables (1999) The Spatial Economy: Cities, Regions and International Trade, MIT Press [Advanced].

Faculty Name
Santu Bera [santu.bera@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course has been designed to equip the students to acquire knowledge of living organisms at the molecular and cellular levels. It will be enabling them to understand the basics of building blocks, life processes, the structures that shape living organisms and function of the human body in health and disease. The course content is: 

1. Molecules of Life

Cellular and chemical foundations of life

1.1 Water :  Unique properties, weak interactions in aqueous systems, ionization of water, buffers.

1.2 Amino acids, peptides and proteins:

Amino acids: Definition, classification & structures. Physico-chemical properties of amino acids. Essential and non-essential amino acids. Synthesis and reaction of amino acids.

Peptides: Peptide bond- definition, structure and geometry of peptide bond. Merrifield solid-phase peptide synthesis. N-terminal and C-terminal amino acid determination.

Proteins: Definition, structure, primary, secondary, tertiary and quaternary structure. Structure of globular proteins .

Biologically important peptides - hormones, antibiotics and growth factors. Multimeric proteins, conjugated proteins and metallo-proteins. Diversity of function.

Protein folding and conformational diseases

1.3 Carbohydrates 

Monosaccharides - structure of aldoses and ketoses, ring structure of sugars, conformations of sugars. Structure of biologically important sugar derivatives, oxidation of sugars. Formation of disaccharides. Polysaccharides – homo- and heteropolysaccharides. Structure and role of proteoglycans, glycoproteins and glycolipids.

1.4 Lipids 

 Building blocks of lipids - fatty acids, glycerol, ceramide. Storage lipids - triacyl glycerol and waxes. Structural lipids in membranes. Lipids as signals, cofactors and pigments.

1.5 Nucleic acids

Nucleotides - structure and properties. Nucleic acid structure – Watson-Crick model of DNA. Structure of major species of RNA - mRNA, tRNA and rRNA. Nucleic acid. Other functions of nucleotides.

2. Biochemical Techniques

    a. Spectroscopic Techniques:  Principles of UV-Visible spectrophotometry, Lambert’s and Beer’s law, Applications of UV-Visible spectrophotometry and fluorescence spectroscopy in analysing biomolecules.

    b. Separation of Biomolecules: Electrophoresis and various centrifugation chromatography.  

3. Enzymology:

Introduction to enzymes and mechanisms of catalysis.

Kinetics of enzymatic reactions and inhibition.

Molecular mechanism and regulation of enzyme activity, Applications of enzymes in biotechnology.    

4. Cell Biology

Tools of Cell Biology: Light, phase contrast and super resolution confocal video microscopy. Histochemical staining techniques of tissue samples.

Structure and function of cellular organelles.

Cellular signalling, cell cycle and apoptosis, molecular basis of cancer biology. Three

5. Immunochemistry and Cellular Immunology:

Introduction to Immune system, Innate and Humoral Immunity.

Molecular basis of humoral and cell mediated immune response

Concepts on the development of monoclonal antibody and single chain antibody. Their applications in diagnostics, therapy and vaccine development. 

Learning Outcomes

Students will be able to understand the properties of biomolecules that help to sustain life

Understand the molecular structure, conformation and functions of biomolecules

Understand different biochemical and molecular biological processes.

Faculty Name
Sandeep Ameta [sandeep.ameta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The biological systems are complex but work as a well-controlled machine which can be engineered for the societal benefit. This course aims at introducing students to the exciting field of synthetic biology to teach them how the biological systems can be reprogramed using synthetic and system approach. The course is divided into three modules (M). M1: Tools of Synthetic Biology which will cover from understanding synthetic availabilities (DNA, RNA, peptides) to manipulation tools (regulators, expression systems). M2: Implementation in Regulation of Biological system. It will cover the basics of gene network organization, regulation, artificial/synthetic networks, and gene circuits. M3: Synthetic Cells and Evolving Systems. This module will cover the work around Minimal Cell Research (Minimal cell/Craig Ventor) and bottom-up approaches (Origins of Life Perspective).

This course requires a basic understanding of Biochemistry, Molecular Biology, and cell biology. Some of the basics required for this course are covered in the following course: Introduction to Biology III: Molecular Genetics and Molecular Biology.

Learning Outcomes

At the end of this course, the students should be familiarized with the following ideas and concepts:

  • Basic principles and tools of synthetic biology.
  • Designing and analysis of gene networks and gene circuits.
  • State of the field and achievements of synthetic biology

This course will be mostly based on research papers and reviews. The following books can be referred to: Synthetic Biology-A Primer (by Geoff Baldwin, Imperial College Press), Synthetic Biology Vol I (Robert Meyers, Wiley Publications).

Indian Macroeconomy and Financial Markets [ECO-3514] [ECO-3514-1]

Faculty Name
Prachi Mishra [prachi.mishra@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is an elective for all Economics Majors, PPE as well as Economics Minor.

India has made huge strides and has grown in leaps and bounds over the last five decades. Average annual growth increased from 3% in 1970s to more than 7% in recent years. This has been concomitant with a sharp reduction in poverty, and vast improvements in infrastructure. At the same time, India has become vastly more integrated in the global economy and financial markets.

Against this background, this is an applied macroeconomics and finance course tailored to the Indian context. The course covers key topics and current issues on the Indian macroeconomy and financial markets, spanning macroeconomic and financial outcomes and policies. The topics include growth, inflation, interest rates, fiscal, external, and financial sectors. While the course focuses on understanding the historical evolution of India’s macroeconomy and financial markets, it would also help students develop a view on the outlook going forward.

Learning Outcomes
  • The course will introduce the Indian macroeconomy and financial markets. The main objective of the course is to help students learn essential tools that can help them scientifically understand the Indian macroeconomy and financial markets; and to help them develop an evidence-based view.  
  • The first half of the course will introduce students to economic growth, inflation, and interest rates.
  • The second half of the course will cover the fiscal and external sectors, and financial markets in the Indian context. 
  • The course will span both historical evolution of macroeconomic and financial sector outcomes and policies; as well as an analysis of the outlook going forward.
  • Students will be using basic skills in Excel and STATA coding.  
  • Students will be given practical problems top of mind for Indian policymakers throughout the semester for problem solving.

description:
Special Topics in Media Analysis [CS-2331] [CS-2331-1]

Faculty Name
Anirban Sen [anirban.sen@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Media is one of the most rapidly changing industries today. Blogging and social media websites have accelerated the velocity of information production and sharing, unlike earlier times, when information production was primarily the monopoly of mass media houses. The lines have indeed blurred between news producers, curators, and commentators. In this course, we will take a multi-layered approach to make sense of the changing media landscape and its implications. Some topics we will study, include:

  • Political bias in mass media vs. social media. Does social media accentuate the biases in mass media, or does it act as an active space for debate/bias mitigation.
  • Interaction between mass media and social media. Is social media a distribution channel for mass media, or a curation and commentary channel?
  • Modeling of information flow on mass media and social media. What kind of information flows where and when in the network? Can information flows be artificially regulated (e.g. to propagate mis-/disinformation or propaganda)?

We will study the basics of social network analysis, graph models, timeline analysis, tools for text analysis of content, entity resolution, and read multi-disciplinary papers from recent conferences and journals in computer science, political science, sociology, and media. In the latter part of the course, we will apply some of these tools and techniques learnt, to analyze content and networks around media. This analysis will aid us in capturing patterns and evolution of media bias and topical discourse, content flow in social media, and user and network characteristics around social media event communities. 

This will be a project based course, students will work in groups and implement largescale data collection and analysis systems. Extensive coding would be a part of the latter half of the course wherein the students will have to implement a complete pipeline as part of their project (starting from data collection, preprocessing/cleaning, storage, to information retrieval).

Learning Outcomes

This paper reading and project based course will enable research thinking among students. Needless to state, it will also introduce them to computational media analysis and its various facets (media and algorithmic bias detection, algorithmic methods to counter such biases, and fake news detection and analysis).

Faculty Name
Shagata Mukherjee [shagata.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Policymakers are increasingly adopting behavioural science to tackle profound policy challenges. While traditional policy tools focus on financial resources, laws and incentives, a behavioural science approach focuses on human biases, heuristics, social norms, and choice architecture. Borrowing from various long-standing disciplines such as psychology, economics, sociology, and neuroscience, behavioural science has helped tackle complex development challenges, such as improving education outcomes by enhancing student learning, raising savings rates, promoting energy and water conservation, improving sanitation practices, empowering women, improving health and nutrition outcomes for women and children and strengthening institutions, among others.

The course teaches to solve complex social problems with a keen understanding of human behaviour. The goal of this course is to help students think creatively and critically about public policy issues by providing an understanding of how behavioral science can be used to understand policies in the real world.  The course will introduce cutting-edge research in behavioral science and its implications for public policy. In this course, students will learn the fundamental principles of applied behavioural science and explore how these principles can be used for public policy and programme implementation, and drive change in the broader social ecosystem through lectures, behavioural games and case studies in the Indian context.

courseTitle: Caste and Tamil Literature in Translation
description:
Caste and Tamil Literature in Translation [ENG-2418] [ENG-2418-1]

Overview

This course takes translation as a method of reading and approaching differences. What does translation do to local understandings of caste? How do translators navigate an intercultural space while extending access to texts and voices? Apart from something being lost, what are some things that are gained in translation? We’ll address these questions by looking at canonical and understudied texts written in Tamil and translated into English, particularly those concerning caste. Texts as wide-ranging as ancient Sangam literature and contemporary Tamil music will be a part of the course. Through the lens of translation theory, we’ll look at how various cultural texts engage the question of caste, inequality, and aesthetics. The course pays particular attention to how writers and translators have dealt with the question of caste and gender together.

     Further, we’ll examine how English interacts with Tamil as a language and worldview. Given that English as a language continues to play an important role in anti-caste politics, the course examines translation’s and the translator’s place in this conversation. Students will learn to appreciate the formal choices that translators make keeping the popular literary conventions of Tamil and English literature in mind, even as they pay close attention to the local context. Familiarity with Tamil is not a requirement for the course.

courseTitle: Eighteenth-Century Literary Forms and Human Rights
description:
Eighteenth-Century Literary Forms and Human Rights [ENG-3309] [ENG-3309-1]

Overview

 What do stories have to do with human rights? Taking this to be the guiding question, this course will introduce students to the role that eighteenth-century literature plays in our understanding of human rights. We will pay attention to both the colonial and anti-colonial ethos of this period to better understand the historical and cultural context in which human rights, as we recognise them today, were fashioned.
     How do human rights travel across geographical boundaries, communities, and literary forms? We’ll study different forms such as the novel, the short story, the lyric, and the slave narrative; and consider them as evolving forms in the long eighteenth century that tussle with the discourse of human rights.
     Students will get acquainted with how scholars of literary studies have deployed decades-long work on the category of the ‘human’ to intervene in the global rise in rights discourse. If literary forms and the law are concerned with constraints, we’ll see how human rights claims at once engage both these boundaries creatively. To this end, we’ll read both canonical texts such as Robinson Crusoe, Equiano’s slave narrative, and also some lesser-known texts such as Mary Robinson’s lyrics, and Veeramamunivar’s The Adventures of Guru Paramartha. The course will familiarise students with the evolution of literary practices and concepts such as ‘self’ and ‘dignity’ that form the fulcrum of human rights today.

description:
Victorian Matters [ENG-4325] [ENG-4325-1]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How does matter matter? We’ll explore this question through different kinds of texts from the nineteenth century, including (mainly) novels, poems, and other literary works, but also some non-fictional writings that approach the matter of matter from a scientific, ecological, or aesthetic perspective. Whereas writing belongs to the realm of the symbolic—of language, representation, and meaning—it is shaped by material realities, and also vividly materialises imagination. We understand, in other words, that literature is shaped by relations of production and of power; but 'material' can also refer to earth, body, cloud, velvet, stone, flame, oranges, dust, gold, grease. As we read and think about materials, we will open text into texture, to ask whether a renewed critical vocabulary can emerge from our consideration -- one that is attuned to the relation of human and non-human; body and ecology; things and forces; space and affect. 

The Victorian period perfectly allows for a juxtaposition of stuff and non-sense with sense and sensibility, given the contending nineteenth-century affinities for science and progress, for vital materialism and occult forces, and for social and psychological realism. We will read through both canonical and lesser-known works from the era (including longer texts by Charles Dickens, Elizabeth Gaskell, George Eliot, and Thomas Hardy; poetry by Alfred Tennyson, Robert Browning, Gerard Manley Hopkins, and shorter works of genre fiction). Alongside, we will also dip into non-fictional archives, including works by Charles Darwin, Michael Faraday, John Ruskin, Walter Pater, and Henry David Thoreau, as well as reading more contemporary theorists of materiality and materialism. As we think about matter, we will inevitably consider what is elusive, illusory, and immaterial.

This course counts towards the MLC concentration.

courseTitle: Introduction to Gilles Deleuze: A Theory of Minor Literature
description:
Introduction to Gilles Deleuze: A Theory of Minor Literature [ENG-4828] [ENG-4828-1]

Faculty Name
Huzaifa Omair Siddiqi [huzaifa.siddiqi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

For Gilles Deleuze, the question we must ask of works of literature is not interpretative (what does it mean?) but experimental (how does it function?). This course will be an experiment in reading Deleuze, seeking an entry point into his thought not through a detailed and rigorous analysis of his works, but through various lines of flight—by exploring what he read and how he read it.

 

We will explore Deleuze's Library of Babel, examining his idiosyncratic readings of authors like Lewis Carroll, Jorge Luis Borges, the Marquis de Sade, Sacher-Masoch, Marcel Proust, Henry Miller, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Herman Melville, Franz Kafka, Henry James, Antonin Artaud, Alfred Jarry, Samuel Beckett, D.H. Lawrence, T.E. Lawrence, Heinrich von Kleist, Walt Whitman, and, of course, Friedrich Nietzsche. In parallel, we will read the works of these authors themselves, comparing Deleuze's interpretations to the original texts. Through this process, we will attempt to understand Deleuze's concept of "minor literature" and how it operates within his philosophical practice.

courseTitle: Queer Bollywood: Screening Desire in Hindi Cinema
description:
Queer Bollywood: Screening Desire in Hindi Cinema [CT-2416] [CT-2416-1]

Faculty Name
Shivangi Jalan [shivangi.jalan_phd21@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How can we tell when a film is queer? While this question has been asked often about films in the West, this course will undertake the novel task of staging a conversation between queer theory and Hindi cinema. How do we look at films and when do we look with desire? Can looking queerly create subjectivities that are uncomfortable? What is the relation between queer representations and queer readings? Is Bollywood’s queer orientation unique or is there something queer about the form of film? Entangling ourselves with these and other questions, this course will meditate upon ideas of identity, spectatorship, power, and sexuality in film. We will watch films like Farhan Akhtar’s Don, Tarun Mansukhani’s Dostana, Nikhil Advani’s Kal Ho Naa Ho, Farah Khan’s Om Shanti Om, alongside reading theoretical texts by Laura Mulvey, Leo Bersani, Diana Fuss, Jacqueline Rose, Lee Edelman, and Christian Metz, among others.

English Vinglish [CT-2418] [CT-2418-1]

Faculty Name
Shubham Gupta [shubham.gupta_phd21@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Is English an Indian language? What does it mean to write in English in India? Is it merely an elite, colonial language? What is its relationship with the ‘bhashas’? Through these questions and more, this course examines the history and politics of the English language in India. We will probe why English literature was introduced as a subject of study in India long before it was institutionalized in Britain, how gender and caste are inextricably tied to the story of English, why English has come to be seen as a ‘neutral’ language for translation, and how English crouches silently while India debates over the question of the national language.  We will spend time with writers like Vikram Seth, Geetanjali Shree, Chetan Bhagat, Anuja Chauhan, Salman Rushdie, Ajay Navaria,  Premchand, Agyeya, Meena Kandasamy, and others. We will also meet theorists like Aamir Mufti, Akshya Saxena, Shefali Chandra, Meenakshi Mukherjee, Harish Trivedi, Gauri Viswanathan, Ulka Anjaria, Rashmi Sadana, Vasudha Dalmia and others. By the end of this course, we will develop a sensitivity to questions of language – literary or otherwise.

courseTitle: War in the Early Modern World
description:
War in the Early Modern World [HIS-3020/ IR-3030] [HIS-3020/ IR-3030-1]

Faculty Name
Pratyay Nath [pratyay.nath@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What did early guns look like? How did the advent of firearms transform military tactics, strategy, and culture in sixteenth-century Japan, Europe, and Korea? What role did military techniques have in the European colonisation of Africa and the Americas? How did warfare relate to the international state-system in Russia, Iran, and the Ottoman Empire? Why did the traditional military use of elephants and horses continue in South Asia and Southeast Asia even after the spread of gunpowder weaponry? These are some of the questions this course addresses. It offers an exploration of the global history of warfare in the early modern world (1500-1800). It especially looks into the rapid changes in technology, tactics, strategy, logistics, and military culture vis-à-vis growing international rivalry between empires and nation-states during this period. We will explore war in the European nation-states, European colonies in the Americas, the Russian Empire, African kingdoms, the Ottoman Empire, Indian empires, the Safavid Empire in Iran, Southeast Asian kingdoms, the Ming and Qing Empires in China, the Tokugawa Shogunate in Japan, the Korean kingdom, and European maritime empires.

NB: This History elective is corss-listed with International Relations.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will have a sound understanding of military history for different parts of the early modern world against the backdrop of the processes of state-formation and empire-building.

courseTitle: Unclaimed Histories: Psychoanalysis as a Historical Method
description:
Unclaimed Histories: Psychoanalysis as a Historical Method [HIS-5600] [HIS-5600-1]

Faculty Name
Aparna Vaidik [aparna.vaidik@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a historical methods course that is woven around historical works that engage with the ‘unruly unconscious’ that expresses itself in the form of flawed testimonies, unprocessed grief, and the silence of trauma. That is, the unclaimed histories of human experiences that tend to fall by the wayside. Given the representational limitations of the evidence-based historical discipline, working with the unconscious disrupts some well-established disciplinary protocols of historiographical practice. It requires a redefinition of the words history, truth, evidence and archive. It also raises some uncomfortable questions such as: How do we attend to the affective dimension of experience - ours and that of historical subjects? How can we subject experiential claims to rigorous investigation and disputation? How does our relationship to a remembered past, or to the past which we imagine is inaccessible to us, serve desires in the present? How do we rethink the complex relationship of narrative structures to truth claims? This course engages with these questions as it takes the students through the writings of historians who successfully adapted psychoanalytic concepts to historical analysis. The course begins with familiarizing the students with a few psychoanalytic concepts that historians tend to draw on followed by weekly segments devoted to a psychoanalytical historical work. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This is a reading-intensive seminar. No lectures. You will have to come prepared to discuss the readings. Please join only if you are curious and enjoy exploring new ideas.

courseTitle: Archive Fever: Representation, Affect, and Historian's Craft
description:
Archive Fever: Representation, Affect, and Historian's Craft [HIS-6500] [HIS-6500-1]

Faculty Name
Aparna Vaidik [aparna.vaidik@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

History as an academic discipline traces back its genealogy to European Enlightenment, a philosophical movement in 17th and 18th century Europe identified with the Age of Reason. The institutionalization and professionalization of History followed in the 19th century. History as a discipline came to be conceived of as a rigorous science based on evidence. Since that time, notwithstanding the intellectual and ideological orientation of a historian, historical inquiry has been premised on gathering and interpretation of evidence. However, the postmodernist critique shook the foundational ideas of the discipline. It questioned the objectivity and stability of historical facts, the historians’ narratives and their epistemic truth. The consequent disciplinary churn led to a  rethinking of the idea of archive and the referential paradigm of the historian’s craft.  This course explores the questions that came to fore in what has come to be known as the ‘archival turn’ in History. These include: Is archive simply a physical repository of historical materials or an idea or a storehouse of memories and dreams? What role does power and privilege play in the creation and one’s access to an archive?  What distortions or accretions does time create in the archival objects? Can the archives be queered? What are the layers of narratives that an archive embodies? What does it visibilize or silence? In what way does the historian's subjectivity and desires mediate their work in the archives? How does one work with archival artifacts - against the grain or along the grain? What is the difference between an extractive and ethnographic approach to the archives? What are the ethics of working with an archive? This course engages with the conceptual writings on archives and seeks to train students in working with different kinds of archival material. The class format will be a combination of discussions on a set of thematic readings followed by a workshop with archival materials. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This is a reading-intensive seminar. No lectures. You will have to come prepared to discuss the readings.

Attendance Policy

You have to attend all classes unless there is a personal emergency.

Reading Iqbal's Javed Nama [HIS-3021] [HIS-3021-1]

Faculty Name
Nadeem Aktar [nadeem.akhtar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Allama Iqbal is hailed as a quintessential figure in modern South Asian scholarship. His contributions to philosophy, law, politics, and literature, have received wide acclaim and continue to be studied.  He wrote with equal faculty in Urdu, Persian, and English, and his proficiency earned him admirers from far beyond South Asia. The genius of his thought and the eloquence of his writing remain unparalleled, yet his work continues to be insufficiently appreciated compared to his Western contemporaries. 

Iqbal’s contribution to Persian literature established him equal in stature to those of the field’s greats. To explore his works in this language, in this course we will read what is popularly considered his magnum opus - the Javid Nama. Written in 1932, it is a narrative style didactic poem, composed in classical Persian verse.  Inspired by Dante’s Divine Comedy, it follows the spiritual journey of Iqbal and his guide Maulana Rumi, as they meet various influential figures in different spheres on their path to reaching the presence of God. 

In this course, we will read sections of the text in its original, Persian. Prior knowledge of the Persian language is therefore mandatory if you wish to enrol in the course. Discussions will be encouraged and students will be expected to participate in class to share their inferences and observations.

Pre-Requisites 

Persian I and II. 

Waivers may be granted to those who can demonstrate proficiency in the Persian language. 

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course, students will have a richer understanding of key sections of the Javid Nama, and hopefully, a greater appreciation for Iqbal’s literary marvel. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The reading materials will be provided in the class.

International History [IR-1010] [IR-1010-1]

Faculty Name
Nayan Ranjan Chanda [nayan.chanda@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, we will analyze the major events of the Cold War through the prism of three analytical lenses: interests, individuals, and ideology. We will attempt to evaluate the extent to which each of these factors, either singly, or in combination, affected decision making on inter-state relations during the decades of the Cold War.

Secondly, the course will also highlight how the progression of the Cold War decades also witnessed the making of deeper inter-connections across the globe. For example, we will consider how the distant developments of the Cold War were also of relevance in shaping India’s position in the world. Furthermore, we will examine how the developments of the Cold War were equally shaped, not just by the superpowers, but also by smaller, poorer, and recently decolonized countries. Enabling an evaluation of why developments unfolded in the way that they did during the Cold War, therefore, the course will show how the appraisal of events from more than a single point of view, is necessary to understand the impact of the Cold War more fully on present day international politics.

Finally, we will also explore the newer directions of the historiography on the Cold War, including the ways in which its debates influenced popular culture and the international perceptions of technological aid. Ultimately, we will ask, in what ways can our analysis of the Cold War help us in shaping our present day understanding of the conduct of international affairs in the present?

Biodiversity is facing an unprecedented risk of extinction. Overview

The body in performance is precariously located between reality and fiction, i.e., between person and character. This precarity is necessarily available to the viewer’s gaze; and this places a significant burden of self-consciousness upon the body. The underlying focus of this course will be to see how the body in performance both negotiates and capitalizes upon this very tentative equation between precarity and visibility.  Many other questions will also be explored: how “self-consciousness”, that is logistically critical to performance, may inspiringly turn “unselfconscious” in performance; wherein lie the slippages and overlaps between self, person and character in performance; how may the performing body present itself to somatically engage gaze and “warm” the eye of the viewer; what is the role of the viewer in allowing the performing body to flourish, and facilitate a shared sympathetic-experience. Keeping our focus on the body's twin instincts, i.e., to be “seen” or seek attention and to play “unselfconsciously”; we will examine it in a variety of performance modes: ritual, entertainment, propaganda, exhibitionistic, aesthetic, instructive, immersive and so on. Special attention will be paid to the place of the body within the scheme of Indian poetics proposed by the Natya Shastra. In addition, the course will also include somatic practice and improvisation.

Learning Outcomes

This course will have a three-pronged focus: theory, somatic practice and improvisation.

The weekly readings will be made available during the previous week.

In addition to the paper, there will also be a final presentation that will be included in the Performing Arts Department’s final showcase. The showcase will be held in the Black Box, most likely during the last week of November. Each student will be expected to participate in this in some capacity or the other.

Faculty Name
Punita Gurpreet Singh [punita.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Much like the Roma community it is associated with, ‘Romani
Music’ defies being defined and confined within boundaries. Since
their exodus from India over a millennium ago, the Roma have
reached all corners of the world, both absorbing and influencing
music en route. While valued and patronized for their musical
skills, many have faced discrimination and exclusion and continue
to lead a marginalized existence on the fringes of mainstream
society in their new homelands. In this course, we explore the role
music has played in forging Roma identity and its potential for
harmonizing cultural relations.
We follow the musical journey of the Roma from India to Europe
and beyond and learn some songs and dances along the way. We
delve into many of the genres clubbed under the term ‘Gypsy
Music’—Romani songs associated with daily life, rites of passage,
festivals and political activism, Manouche and Sinti Swing, Gypsy
Jazz, Hungarian Ciganyzene, Romanian Lautari, Fanfare and
Manele, Bulgarian Chalga, Balkan Pop, and Spain’s national
treasure—Flamenco. We will also look for vestiges of the Indian
origin in the music and explore the impact the ‘Gypsy style’ has
had on composers of western classical music.

Overview

This course will be based on a close reading of a representative sample of Nietzsche’s works together with discussion of some of his main themes. The works will include The Birth of Tragedy, “On the Uses and Disadvantages of History for Life,” “On Truth and Lie in a Non-Moral Sense,” The Gay Science, Thus Spoke Zarathustra and Ecce Homo. The themes will include Truth and Perspectivism, the Will to Power, the Death of God, Eternal Recurrence, the Free Spirit, Revaluation of All Values, the Body and Nietzsche’s Styles.

Learning Outcomes

On completion of this course students will:

* Have an understanding of the development of Nietzsche’s authorship.

* Have an understanding of some of Nietzsche’s key themes and concepts.

* Have developed a critical perspective on some of Nietzsche’s central themes.

* Have developed the capacity to ask critical questions regarding the texts.

Grading Rubric

Presentation Grading Rubric

Clarity of exposition. You will receive marks for giving a clear exposition of themes and concepts and for explaining difficult sections of the text.

Demonstrating understanding of the text. You will receive marks for showing that you have understood the text, particularly those parts whose meaning is not obvious.

Raising questions about the text. You will receive marks for raising questions about the text. You will receive marks for the quality of the questions, whether for their critical acumen or for the way in which they orient readings of the text or for the way in which they reflect genuine perplexity about the text.

Promotion of Discussion. You will receive marks for promoting discussion of the text among your classmates. You will earn marks especially for promoting critical discussion or insightful discussion.

Final Essay Plan & Bibliography Grading Rubric

Your plan will be graded on its clarity, comprehensiveness, originality of the topic, selection of primary and secondary resources and its organisation into a potentially coherent argument or narrative.

Final Essay Grading Rubric

Quality of the Question. You will receive marks for (1) relevance of your question, (2) originality of your question, (3) significance of your question (does it open up interesting or important perspectives on the target texts?), (4) answerability of your question (is it really able to be answered?), (5) scope of the question (is it able to be answered adequately in 500 words?), (6) Clarity of your question (make sure your question is not muddled or ambiguous).

Answer to the Question. Does your answer actually answer the question you have posed? Is your answer clear and well-formulated? 

Evidence for your Answer. Do you support your answer with evidence? Do you draw on evidence from the target texts? Do you introduce extra-textual evidence (context, theoretical perspectives)? 

Coherence of your Essay. You will be evaluated on the coherence of the evidence and argument, or narrative, you create to answer the question. One form of coherence would be to offer your answer as the conclusion to an argument, in which your evidence forms the premises of your argument. Narrative coherence is somewhat looser, though should be devoid of inconsistencies. It should also offer a compelling answer to your question.

Overview

WRITING MEMOIR -- The transformative power of personal writing

As one sifts through memories, emotions and personal experience to connect the personal to the universal, writing about one's life can be a healing and transformative journey, both for the writer as well as readers. This course offers an empathetic, nurturing space with creative prompts, writing exercises, readings, analysis and feedback to develop one's unique voice and write compelling essays that are intimate, thought-provoking and deeply honest.

In this course over three months, we will deconstruct sound and explore the building blocks of audio from the lens of its Nature, Behaviour and Interaction. This will guide us through the levels of intervention that can be done in pre and post-production through Digital Audio Workstations (DAW) to construct and curate the steps in sound processing. These techniques of bending sound can be applied to all forms of sound in various media; be it podcasting, audiobooks, music production, sound design and sound art. AI and Philosophy [PHI-2188] [PHI-2188-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Iain Siantonas [alexander.siantonas@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

 

Philosophers have long been concerned with questions under the broad heading of ‘the relationship between mind and world’. This interest, meanwhile, has never been confined to the human mind: the minds of God and other supposed spiritual beings have often been popular topics. But never before have we had such compelling candidates to qualify as synthetic minds, about which we may ask all of the old questions anew. What goes on when an AI categorises an image? Does an AI represent the world, and if so, how? How can we interpret those representations? Do they have knowledge? Desires? Can they know and desire what’s good? This course will address such questions using a range of sources: core philosophical works from Aristotle onwards; contemporary philosophical discussions of AI; and broader commentary on AI for a general audience.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students should be able to understand a range of issues raised by AI, as well as questions of general philosophical interest; they should be able to criticise and construct philosophical arguments about AI.

Faculty Name
Debayan Gupta [debayan.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course presents an in-depth study of cryptography and its applications to information and computer security. It serves as an introduction to modern cryptography, emphasizing its classical goals: data privacy, authenticity, and integrity. It covers the fundamentals of both symmetric-key and public-key cryptography. Additionally, the course introduces advanced cryptography concepts, including commitment schemes, secret sharing, oblivious transfer, zero-knowledge proofs, and multi-party computation.

Privacy and security are central to our emerging “information society”, and cryptography is a key technology for achieving them; it is also a fascinating field of study in its own right. Cryptography lies at the center of this course, but we will be approaching the subject broadly. On the one end, we’ll look at problems of computer and information security and see how cryptographic tools can be used to solve them. We’ll also touch on some social issues surrounding the use of cryptography. At the other end, we’ll explore the mathematical structures from which cryptographic primitives are built, and learn how to use some of these techniques in real-world scenarios.

Information security, broadly defined, involves controlling the dissemination of information. It includes issues of privacy, data integrity, authenticity, and authority. Because of the ease with which information can be copied and transmitted, traditional physical means of control are of limited efficacy. Cryptography gives a way to build logical controls on the flow of information that are largely independent of the physical properties of the devices used to transmit and store information. In addition to this, while we may rely on cryptography for access control and protection of sensitive data, computer security also includes topics such as physical security, access restrictions, activity monitoring, and control of software defects that go way beyond what will be covered in this course.

Broadly, we will cover:

  • Symmetric key cryptography: Symmetric Key Encryption, Pseudorandom number generators (PRG), Pseudorandom functions (PRF), Stream ciphers, Block ciphers, Modes of Operations, Security definitions for Encryption, Message integrity, Message authentication codes, Hash Functions.
  • Public key cryptography: Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange, Discrete Logarithm Problem. Public key encryption, Security definitions, Factoring Problem, ElGamal  Encryption, RSA Encryption. Digital Signatures, RSA Signature, DSA Signature. Introduction to Elliptic Curve, ECDSA Signature.  
  • Applications: Public key infrastructure (PKI), Brief Introduction to TLS.
  • Advanced Cryptography Concepts: Commitment Schemes, Secret Sharing, Oblivious Transfer, Zero knowledge Proofs, Multiparty Computation.
Learning Outcomes

You will have a solid understanding of the mathematical tools for cryptography; symmetric and public key cryptographic techniques as DES, RSA, and zero-knowledge proofs, and their application to problems of maintaining privacy and security in computer networks (such as digital signatures and key management). You will also understand - at a deep, technical level - ideas such as identity, authentication, and verfiability.

You wil also learn to appreciate societal issues as balancing individual privacy concerns against the needs of law enforcement, vulnerability of societal institutions to electronic attack, export regulations and international competitiveness, and development of secure information systems.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

I will provide detailed lecture notes covering everything you need. Any other content/textbooks will be either optional or available for free on the internet.

Faculty Name
Aalok Dhaval Thakkar [aalok.thakkar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Symbolic logic presents an intriguing challenge in computer science: balancing the need to express complex ideas with the ability to solve problems efficiently. This course explores how we can create systems that are powerful enough to describe useful scenarios, yet still allow computers to reason about them effectively. We'll examine various approaches to this balance, learning how theorists and practitioners have developed ways to represent knowledge and automate reasoning. Without requiring any prior background in logic or advanced mathematics, this course offers a gentle yet rigorous introduction to deductive systems, propositional and predicate calculi, and higher-order logic. We will also learn about the applications of these formalisms to constraint solving, program verification, automated reasoning, and interactive theorem proving. Please refer to the detailed course webpage with prerequisites, resources, course outline, calendar, and other logistics. 

The objectives of this course are to:

  1. Develop a foundation in the core concepts and deductive systems of propositional logic, predicate logic, and higher-order logics, including their syntax, semantics, and proof techniques,
  2. Gain knowledge of the practical applications of symbolic logic in a variety of domains, such as constraint solving, program verification, automated reasoning, and interactive theorem proving,
  3. Understand the trade-off between expressiveness and algorithmic tractability in logical formalisms, and the importance of finding reasonable compromises between these conflicting goals,
  4. Understand the fundamental limitations of formal logic, reasoning, and computation, and
  5. Develop hands-on experience working with tools like SAT solvers and interactive theorem provers, bridging the gap between theoretical reasoning and practical considerations.

This course builds upon concepts such as set theory, relations, and proofs covered in Quantitative Reasoning and Mathematical Thinking (FC-0306), Introduction to Computer Science (CS-1101/1102), and Discrete Mathematics (CS-1104). It also provides essential skills for analyzing and reasoning about the concepts covered in Data Structures (CS-1203), Design and Analysis of Algorithms (CS-1205/1206), Theory of Computation (CS-1349/2349) Programming Language Design and Implementation (CS-1319). This course serves as a foundation for advanced electives in computer science including interactive theorem proving, model checking and verification, computational complexity theory, and Artificial Intelligence (CS-2322). This course overlaps with Symbolic Logic (PHI-1060/CS-2160).

Learning Outcomes

The objectives of this course are to:

  1. Develop a foundation in the core concepts and deductive systems of propositional logic, predicate logic, and higher-order logics, including their syntax, semantics, and proof techniques,
  2. Gain knowledge of the practical applications of symbolic logic in a variety of domains, such as constraint solving, program verification, automated reasoning, and interactive theorem proving,
  3. Understand the trade-off between expressiveness and algorithmic tractability in logical formalisms, and the importance of finding reasonable compromises between these conflicting goals,
  4. Understand the fundamental limitations of formal logic, reasoning, and computation, and
  5. Develop hands-on experience working with tools like SAT solvers and interactive theorem provers, bridging the gap between theoretical reasoning and practical considerations.

All resources and reading materials are provided here.

A serious student of a subject is not an idle spectator to a variety show but learns best by active involvement. This is particularly true of mathematical subjects. This course is structured to incentivise involvement through the following:

This hands-on experience allows for practical application of course concepts and fosters deeper engagement with the subject matter covered in Module 3. The project may be done either alone or in pairs. Project topic needs to be approved by the instructor. It carries 20% of the grade.
  3. Assignments: The course includes 10 problem sets. These are designed to reinforce lecture material and develop practical skills in applying theoretical concepts. They constitute 30% of the grade.
  4. Examination: Two in-class, closed-book, 1.5 hour examinations carry the remaining 45% of the grade. Students are permitted to bring a single, two-sided "cheat sheet" of their own creation.

Faculty Name
