Overview

In many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), agri-food systems can be instrumental in not only reducing poverty and hunger, but also ensuring sustainable food and nutrition security; healthy populations and environment; efficient use of resources, and resilience to shocks and crises. The objective of this course is to introduce students to the concept of agri-food systems, their role in economic development, why and how they should/could be transformed to be sustainable, resilient, and inclusive in providing livelihoods and nutritious, safe, accessible, affordable, and sufficient food for current and future generations. The course will focus on topics such as global trends in food demand and supply; the roles of organizations, institutions, policy and technology, as well as shocks and crises (such as climate change and COVID-19) on agri-food systems, and will highlight national, regional and global level opportunities and challenges for LMICs to transform their agri-food systems into one that produces sufficient, affordable, accessible, culturally acceptable, safe and nutritious food for all its citizens. In addition to providing the theoretical framework and the latest literature on each topic, each session may also feature an invited guest speaker from the field, and where appropriate will feature to make the topics and working thereon more relatable and accessible to those who may want to work in this field. All these themes will be presented and discussed with an equity and social justice lens.  In each class students will have opportunities to present, discuss or debate the topics, and in a few of the classes, experts from the field from within Ashoka or outside will be invited to share their points of view and discuss opportunities and challenges of working in their fields.

courseTitle: An Interpretive History of Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Revolution
description:
An Interpretive History of Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Revolution [HIS-4802/ CHI-4001/ POL-3090/ IR-3027] [HIS-4802/ CHI-4001/ POL-3090/ IR-3027-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Revolution 101: An Interpretive History of Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Revolution

CHI-4001/HIS-4802/POL-3090

Monsoon 2024

Tuesdays & Thursdays 11.50-1.20 pm AC04-LR-307

Sayantani Mukherjee – sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in – AC02-339

This course introduces the historical relationship between Mao Zedong’s philosophy of history and revolution, and the global context of Chinese Revolution in the twentieth century. We will examine Mao’s theories and practice of revolution through a thematic lens: not as biographical artifacts but as thought produced by and constitutive of the revolutionary circumstances in the twentieth-century world at large and China in particular.  Our aim will be to investigate how three modal terms—Chinese, Revolutionary, Marxist—reflect on each other as open questions when Mao Zedong is studied in contextually-embedded and philosophically complex manner.

Situating the world in an intimate dialogic relationship to China, we will ask the questions; was Mao a Marxist? How was Mao’s Marxism inflected by his positionality of being Chinese in a revolutionary twentieth-century world? How was Mao’s Chineseness influenced by his being a revolutionary in the twentieth-century world? How was Marxism impacted by Mao’s articulation of revolution in the twentieth-century world? The readings for this class will mostly be drawn from Mao’s own writings, and students will be expected to read these texts intensively, with an open mind. While this course does not require any previous knowledge of China, as an advanced level class, a familiarity with general twentieth-century world history and/or a background in the history of Marxism will be helpful. Students with prior background in neither will be expected to learn on a very steep curve.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Objectives:

Read intertextually and understand literary productions as artefacts of historical and social construction.

Summarize academic monographs in East Asian studies and introduce salient points in notes and in speech.

Be able to draw connections between works to gain an overview of scholarly and historiographical debates.

Be able to trace theoretical or methodological trends across multiple empirical contexts.

Learn the skills of co-writing and co-presenting to gain a sense of how cooperative work can integrate intellectual property as well as collective clarity.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required Texts:

You are not required to purchase any materials for this course. All readings will be provided in PDF via email.

Grading Rubric

Assessment & Assignments:

30% - Regular participation in class discussions

70% - Writing Portfolio (summarized below):

10% - Progress meetings (minimum 2)

40% - Report

20% - Op-ed

Attendance Policy

Attendance, Participation and Discussion Étiquette:

One third of your grade in this class depends on learning how to read written productions “against the grain”. That is to say, scrutinizing the beliefs and attitudes that typically go unexamined in a text, drawing attention to the gaps, silences, contradictions, and unspoken impetus that animate written words, but also reading that text through the various registers of its production and circulation—as an artefact of literary, historical and social conditions that may or may not alter its imagined “original” context. We are reading Mao, but we will never take him for his word.

I will not take attendance in each class meeting, however, participation in weekly class discussions is a mandatory part of your grade and is necessary for succeeding in the course. If you have circumstances that might affect attendance at a specific class meeting, please let me know ahead of time whenever possible. Flexibility is especially important since Covid is still with us. To protect your privacy, please do not describe any medical situations to me; just inform me that the situation exists and be prepared to provide a doctor’s note if requested.

Participation is part of your grade, and should be based on attentive reading, listening, and preparation. Always keep an open mind and be respectful of your classmates and your instructor regardless of what you wish to say, or whether you agree with what has already been said. Being respectful also means that (1) if you have not completed a particular reading, please refrain from commenting on it (2) in the normal course of discussion, if you have just spoken, you should refrain from speaking again until others who wish to contribute have done so (3) contributions to discussion should be based on the readings, lectures, and discussion questions, and should aim to improve our collective understanding of them. In general, please avoid unstructured/unsupported reflections as well as topics that are beyond the scope of the course.

Overview

"Being an early career artist sucks. You're fed up of hearing, "OMG, ur so talented, u shud turn dis into a side business fr!!" but you're also not quite at the point where anyone wants to pay real money for an aesthetic that is purely yours. This apparent dichotomy of popular-but-soulless and authentic-but-ignored is as much a product of mass market homogenisation as it is of artists' dogmatic adherence to their initial visions. This visual arts course won't prevent you from becoming a hustler in the side-gig economy but it will help you find your niche at the crucial overlap of public approval and your personal excesses.

Over the semester, we will refine your authentic, personal aesthetic/brand/style(/vibe/drip/mood) and iteratively find means and methods of artistic expression for it - ones that can exist confidently beyond the corners of notebooks or dorm rooms. Lectures, workshops, in-class demos and exercises will guide students through different media and artforms, and expose them to novel approaches for and applications of their artistic talent. Students will work towards a final project that will be a public showcase of their work, be it in the form of an art installation or gallery, a series of paintings or prints, physical creations, photoessays, or even something as simple as branded merch.

While the course may sound like it is geared more towards artists with experience, it will be just as (if not more) useful for those with a keen interest but insufficient prior exposure to visual art."

courseTitle: Advanced Quantum Mechanics: Open Quantum Systems and Quantum Information
description:
Advanced Quantum Mechanics: Open Quantum Systems and Quantum Information [PHY-4540/ PHY-6541] [PHY-4540/ PHY-6541-1]

Faculty Name
Arjendu Kishore Pattanayak [arjendu.pattanayak@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Scope and goals:
We are in the middle of the 2nd quantum revolution resulting from our understanding over the last
100 years that quantum mechanics -- including unusual things like entanglement and
measurement collapse -- carries great explanatory power and considerable technological
advantages over classical systems. There is a rapidly growing and well-funded ‘quantum
information’ industry while we begin to address still-difficult engineering challenges. These are the
NISQ (noisy intermediate scale quantum) systems to which this course will introduce you. By the
end you should be able to read some of the literature and get started on individual work.

Course Outline
We will follow the following sequence, with approximately a week spent on each topic, including
some time for review. Lectures will review and distill assigned readings. Weekly problems and
worksheets will be assigned to make ideas concrete.


A: Quantum basics
1. States and operators in Dirac notation, Hilbert space, effect of measurement
2. Density operators and ensembles
3. Composite quantum systems and properties, partial trace for subsystem projections


B: Open quantum systems
4. Kraus operator formalism, decoherence, quantum open system Lindblad dynamics
5. Trajectory ‘unraveling’ of density operator dynamics, stochastic Schrodinger equation
6. Measurement choices, Hilbert space trajectories


C: Quantum information and processing
7. Quantum information embedded in states; measurement effects
8. Quantum key distribution
9. Quantum processing and quantum circuits
10. Quantum algorithms: Detusch-Josza, dense coding, teleportation, Grover search


D: Special topics
11. Physical implementations of quantum information processing
12. Current research and independent readings

 

 

 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites:
1. A previous course in quantum mechanics [PHY3510 - Quantum Mechanics or equivalent]
2. Comfort with linear algebra and complex numbers

Background resources include
A:
1. Hilbert Space including composite systems from “Thinking Quantum”: Lectures on
Quantum Theory, B Shoshany, arXiv:1803.07098
B:
2. Open systems from “Lecture Notes on the Theory of Open Quantum Systems”, D Lidar,
arXiv:1902.00967, 2019
3. Quantum state trajectories from “Quantum State Diffusion”, I Percival, Cambridge
University Press, 1998
4. Measured trajectories from “The emergence of chaos in continuously measured quantum
systems,” J. Eastman The Australian National University (Australia) ProQuest Dissertations
Publishing, 2019.
C:
5. Quantum information and quantum computing from “Quantum Computing: A gentle
introduction” by E. Rieffel and W Polak, MIT Press, 2014.
6. Youtube lectures by Tim Byrnes Overview : Introduction to quantum computing course
D: Literature/colleagues/talks.


This is an advanced undergraduate or a Master’s level course. However, the only pre-requisites are
understanding linear algebra, complex numbers, and at least one course in quantum mechanics.

The final grade/assessment will be based on 2 mid-term ‘tests’ (50%), regular HW or worksheets
(20%), engagement (15%), and a final independent paper created from literature review (15%)

Overview

This is an introductory course on health informatics, where we will cover existing health informatics tools within hospitals to capture and safeguard patient health data and build innovations (research and development) for better patient care. This course will provide an introductory level understanding of health informatics such as electronic medical records (EMR), electronic health records (EHR), medical vocabularies (SNOMED CT, LIONIC, ICD9 etc), open community standards such as common data model, and most importantly how to integrate innovations (research and development) on top of the EHR systems. The course's second half will focus on Clinical Trials & Evidence-based Medicine using statistical machine-learning methods.

Eligibility criteria:

Suitable for UG 3rd year / ASP / MSc 1 year

Learning Outcomes

 

  • Students will know about existing information technology for healthcare such as electronic health records (EHR), and electronic medical records (EMR); and how they work from the point of view of hospital administration, physicians/clinicians, nurses and patient care with the hospital ecosystem and beyond hospital ecosystem services such as mobile technologies.
  • Appreciate the need for reliable evidence-generation methodology that can inform clinical decision-making
  • Understand the differences between different study designs and the methods of interpreting a study results and the statistical principles underlying such inference
    • Prospective versus Retrospective
    • Experimental versus Observational
  • Appreciate the pros and cons of observational studies as methods for generating medical evidence  the challenges in inferring causality
  • Appreciate how experimental results may be interpreted within a probabilistic framework, as well as the limitations of the experimental method and safeguards needed for experimenting with human subjects.
  • Understand commonly used observational designs, their strengths and limitations and key statistical considerations in their design.
  • Appreciate and get an overview of common approaches for adjusting for exposure likelihood and confounding.

Faculty Name

Overview

The human body is home to trillions of microorganisms that help us perform many important biological functions. Studying the microbiome is currently an evolving field with lots of challenges and opportunities. As such, the human microbiome plays an important role in maintaining homeostasis and normal function throughout the human body, and changes in microbiota affect human health adversely. This course aims to provide an overview of the complexity of the human microbiome, molecular basis of microbiota-host interactions in various diseases, and how microbiota can be targeted for development of new therapeutic approaches.

 

Learning Outcomes

After completing this course students should:
1. Understand the biology, diversity, and utility of microorganisms.
2. Explain what the microbiome is.
3. Describe how microbiota benefits the human body.
4. Explain how changes in microbiome are associated with adverse health outcomes.
5. Explain how microbiota affects nutrition and metabolism.
6. Describe how microbiota targeting therapies work and what are the current challenges related to microbiome research.

In addition, by reading and evaluating relevant articles, students will become familiar with approaches used to solve research problems concerning microorganisms.

Brief Course Outline: The couse will begin with a introduction to microorganisms, microbial diversity, understanding microbial nutrition, and the roles of microbes in environment. Thereafter, classes will focus on the Human microbiome and its role in development of diseases, nutrition and metabolism, and the gut-brain axis. Along with this, few lectures will focus on microbiota modulation and how to study of microbiome/s.

Overview

Evolutionary thinking is rather pervasive. Its applications are not only limited to all subdisciplines of biology but also across a range of fields outside biology, from cosmology to town building. Evolutionary computation is a distinguished field now enabling solutions to inherently complex systems.

In this course, I plan to lay a firm foundation of evolutionary theory with the help of basic principles of genetics along with the tools of mathematics and computation. This will be followed by connecting those concepts to the essence of modern omics techniques, human health, and evolutionary medicine.

This course does not need any prerequisites, except for 10th standard mathematics. All other necessary concepts will be taught during the course itself. However, an introduction to genetics, 12th-grade Mathematics, a basic knowledge of coding in any programming language and will be helpful (but not essential) for this course.

Learning Outcomes

Strong foundational knowledge of the principles behind evolutionary thinking and experimentation.

Metaphysics: Time, Change and Causation [PHI-2005/ PHI-2392] [PHI-2005/ PHI-2392-1]

Faculty Name
Arindam Chakrabarti [arindam.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Metaphysics--also called “Ontology”—is “First Philosophy” according to Aristotle. The Sanskrit term “padãrtha” literally “what a word means” also captures the notion of an ontological category, such as the category of substance, quality, events, universals, relation, absence etc. Metaphysics, whether it is done in Greek, Latin or any modern European language, studies the nature of different types of entities that really exist. In this class we shall explore some central ontological questions of contemporary interest, from both classical Indian (including Buddhist) as well as contemporary Western perspectives.

 Seven major questions about the nature and reality of Time, Change, Causation and Nonexistence will be discussed, on the basis of close reading of classical Indian (translated from Sanskrit) and modern Western (English) texts.

1. Where did the universe come from? Did the world have a beginning or no beginning? (Vedas, and Kant’s first antinomy of pure reason)

2. Is time real, independently of our experience of time? Are Numbers timelessly real? What is Space? Could Time and Space be regarded as SUBSTANCES (Newton) or as RELATIONS (Leibniz) only ?

3. Does the effect pre-exist in the material cause?

4. Is the Buddhist proof of the momentariness of all that exists logically sound?

5. What are the different kinds of causes (for Aristotle and Nyāya-vaiśeṣika)?

6. Is there an objective causal connection between events in the world out there? (David Hume and Galen Strawson)

7. Are there absences, distinctions, gaps, lacks and other negative things in reality? What is the ontological status of Zero as a number?

For majors, minors, and so on in Philosophy, PPE, PHICS, PSYPHI this course can count for CC or for IN. For CC, enroll in PHI-2005. For IN, enroll in PHI-2392.

C. Attendance and Oral Participation in class (10)

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tushar Ramesh Jaruhar [tushar.jaruhar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The evolution of computing power along with large amounts of data that is being collected has
transformed the world of finance. An example of this is algorithmic trading where an algorithm uses
trading data to determine when you should buy or sell a stock in the market. It becomes more
interesting when the income tax department assess a lot of data about individual taxpayers and
determines that some of the citizens are not paying enough in taxes. The third example is based on
the idea of who should be given a credit card. Most people who have high savings qualify for a credit
card but what about those people who have low to medium savings. What about students at
Ashoka?
Many of these decisions in finance, such as selling a stock, obtaining a credit card, and identifying
defaulters, are based on technology, mathematical algorithms, and knowledge of finance. A person
who masters these 3 fields can work for large companies, set-up their own start-up, trade in the
markets, pursue a career in research, become a financial consultant and pursue many more
opportunities than what is mentioned here.
The course starts with a brief understanding of markets and data that we can obtain for these
markets. Then we look at how to use this data to decide if we should buy or sell a stock or bond.
After having evaluated it heuristically we try to explore algorithms that can fit the behaviour of the
data and perhaps indicate the buy and sell decision.
Similarly, we apply this broad principle of identifying the data, examining it and then determining
which model should be fitted to different problems in finance including predicting stock price,
detecting fraud, providing credit, pricing options, sizing of companies based on financial attributes.
Companies worldwide are looking for talented people who can understand different parts of finance
and apply the right tools and techniques to analyze the products, customers and services. Our goal is
to provide students an opportunity to learn these skills and see challenging careers in finance
globally.
It is oriented towards undergraduates who may not necessarily have coding skills. The audience is
expected to have the willingness to learn and explore. The focus will be to help students create a
portfolio of projects where they can demonstrate the application of data analytics.

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sridhar Sethuraman [sridhar.sethuram@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The rapid growth of Institutional Capital deployed within emerging markets, incl India, has created significant opportunities for entrepreneurs across a variety of sectors, incl the social impact sector. Institutional Capital denotes all types of capital including Grants, Angel, Seed Venture Capital Private Equity, and long-term Hedge Funds. This course will offer students the opportunity to hear of, and participate in, the opportunities and challenges facing institutional investors. The course will include India specific case studies and sharing of experiences of successful investors and entrepreneurs. It covers several industries incl Real Estate, Fin Tech, Social enterprises, and Ecommerce. 

 

The course is based on the fundamental premise that the personal life & career of every individual is also one of an investor and entrepreneur (everyone has to have an entrepreneur mindset whether salaried or an entrepreneur). Students can apply the same investment principles when taking decisions in professional life – incl. when they decide their career choices (where to invest the time capital of life).  And that their professional journey post-graduation on the 4 pillars of any investment: Risk-Return –Investment-Mindset will mirror the life cycle of any enterprise from a startup (risk seeking) to VC to PE (more conservative) to finally being a Listed company where employers will sell and exit if they do not perform (with multiple turnarounds on the journey). 

 

While this course uses the field of unlisted investments as an anchor, the paramount learning outcome it seeks to deliver to help the participant build a muscle of identifying and having courage to a) admitting about matters we think we don’t know b) identify the matters which are important for you and your success in life and c) building a mental process to go out and understand them and learn. You will also experience the stultifying power of fear of failure and helplessness that inhibits success in any investment decision (incl.  your decision to invest time and credits in this course)
